Provides a basic introduction to speech articulation, phonetics, speech acoustics, and perception, with a special emphasis on measurement and analysis of the speech signal. Computer-based laboratory exercises in speech recording, digitization, analysis, variation, synthesis and perception.

CGSC 360.name: Aural Rehabilitation
CGSC 360.descr: This course is designed to apply the concepts of hearing, hearing loss, the physics of sound and hearing technologies to the process of communication. Students will learn how to apply audiological results to speech perception. The course will also explore techniques and technologies to improve both receptive and expressive communication skills in persons with reduced hearing. This class will discuss all age groups with an emphasis on pediatric patients.

CGSC 375.name: Introduction to Communication Disorders in Children
CGSC 375.descr: Introduces students to the field of pediatric communication disorders. It examines the complex behaviors of speech, language and hearing and changes in communicative behaviors in children, arising from biological, environmental, and other factors.

CGSC 376.name: Introduction to Communication Disorders of Adulthood
CGSC 376.descr: Provides an introduction to the field of communication disorders. Examines the complex behaviors of speech, language and hearing and their changes throughout the lifespan, as well as the variety of communication disorders arising from biological, environmental and behavioral factors.

CGSC 377.name: Critical Thinking in a Clinical Setting
CGSC 377.restrict: Open only to CGSC majors in the Speech Pathology track.

CGSC 378.name: Anatomy and Physiology of Speaking
CGSC 378.descr: Introduction to structures and processes underlying human speech production. Anatomical, physiological and neurological bases of speech-related processes, including breathing, phonation and articulation. Primary emphasis is to learn names and functions of various structures involved in speech production and to gain understanding of how they serve to support speaking in normally functioning humans.
CGSC 378.preReq: A grade of “C” or better in CGSC375 or CGSC 376.

CGSC 379.name: Introduction to Audiology
CGSC 379.descr: Provides an overview to the field of audiology. Content includes a study of the anatomy and physiology of the hearing mechanism, hearing assessment, classification of hearing disorders, auditory pathologies, and management of hearing loss.
CGSC 379.preReq: Grade of C or better in CGSC375 or CGSC 376; LING 101.

CGSC 380.name: Clinical Principles and Procedures in Speech Pathology
CGSC 380.descr: Focuses on clinical principles and procedures in assessment, planning and intervention in speech pathology. Assessment issues related to measurement concepts and descriptive statistics including the use of norm- referenced tests, defining target behaviors and developing observation skills are covered. Treatment planning and intervention include developing a treatment program, getting target behavior baselines and documenting treatment effectiveness.
CGSC 380.preReq: Grade of C or better in CGSC 375; CGSC 376; LING 101.

CGSC 404.name: Animal Minds
CGSC 404.descr: Examines philosophical, theoretical, and methodological issues raised by study of animal cognition and behavior. Topics may include mental continuity between human and nonhuman animals, animal communication and deception, self-recognition, emotions, culture, as well as the ethical treatment of animals.
CGSC 404.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

CGSC 410.name: Embodied Cognition
CGSC 410.descr: An examination of the thesis that cognition is not sandwiched between the perceptual input and motor output systems, but is spread across the sensory-motor system. This thesis breaks with classical cognitivisms claim that cognition performs computations on symbols, without regard to the sensory system or the motor system.
CGSC 410.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

CGSC 418.name: Meaning and Language Use
CGSC 418.descr: Introduction to theories of meaning based on the notion of truth and their application to language use.

CGSC 420.name: Research Methods in Cognitive Science
CGSC 420.descr: Cognitive science is a multi-disciplinary approach to the study of mind. Provides a practical and hands-on introduction to specific research methods from one or more disciplines (e.g. computational neuroscience modeling, experimental psychology related to cognitive science, or anthropological and linguistic research methods).
CGSC 420.preReq: PSYC 209 or MATH 201 or MATH 205 or STAT 200 or SOCI 301.

CGSC 421.name: Philosophy, Biology, Society
CGSC 421.descr: Recent topics in philosophy of biology, with emphasis on those related to self, community, and society at large. Topics may include intelligent design, evolutionary altruism, psychological altruism, evolutionary psychology, cultural evolution, evolutionary game theory, and evolutionary ethics.
CGSC 421.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CGSC 433.name: Introduction to Acoustic Phonetics
CGSC 433.descr: Introduction to articulatory, acoustic, and perceptual characteristics of speech with emphasis on the acoustic properties of phonemes. While primarily lecture format with assigned text, a few laboratory sessions provide an introduction to computer-based methods used in instrumental studies of speech.

CGSC 451.name: Topics in Cognitive Science
CGSC 451.restrict: May be repeated for credit when topics vary.

CGSC 455.name: Computational Linguistics
CGSC 455.descr: Natural language can be studied from a computational perspective. Course content includes aspects of formal language theory, model theory, formal grammars, computational complexity, and computational learning theory as it pertains to natural language syntax, semantics, morphology, and phonology.

CGSC 470.name: Elements of Cognitive Science
CGSC 470.descr: Introduction to the interdisciplinary study of the mind. Concentrates on the symbolic view of mind, and illustrates linguistic, psychological, anthropological, philosophical and computational approaches to language, thought, visual perception and other areas of cognition. Examines the role of representation and algorithm in theories of processing and development.

CGSC 471.name: Discovering Human Language
CGSC 471.descr: Introduction to field linguistics. Examines how languages are put together through a face-to-face encounter with an unknown language. Determine how this language - and human language in general - is constructed. Explores culture, people and even the food where the language is spoken.
CGSC 471.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

CGSC 481.name: Artificial Intelligence
CGSC 481.descr: Programming techniques for problems not amenable to algorithmic solutions. Problem formulation, search strategies, state spaces, applications of logic, knowledge representation, planning and application areas.
CGSC 481.preReq: CISC 220 with a minimum grade of C-, CISC 304.
CGSC 481.restrict: Students who received credit in CISC681 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CGSC 485.name: Seminar in Cognitive Science
CGSC 485.descr: Intensive interdisciplinary study of topics in linguistics & cognitive science. Allows students to synthesize what they have learned in previous coursework by bringing together divergent methodologies and applying them to topics in cognitive psychology, speech-language pathology, mind & language, science of language, and philosphical aspects of cognitive science.&nbsp;
CGSC 485.restrict: May be repeated for credit as topic changes.

CGSC 490.name: Philosophy of Language
CGSC 490.descr: Traditional scientific and philosophical issues associated with theories of meaning and reference of language.

CGSC 496.name: Psycholinguistics
CGSC 496.descr: An introduction to psycholinguistics, the study of the psychological processing of linguistic information at the levels of speech sounds, words, memory, sentences and meaning.

CGSC 610.name: Embodied Cognition
CGSC 610.descr: An examination of the thesis that cognition is not sandwiched between the perceptual input and motor output systems, but is spread across the sensory-motor system. This thesis breaks with classical cognitivism’s claim that cognition performs computations on symbols, without regard to the sensory system or the motor system.

CGSC 618.name: Meaning and Language Use
CGSC 618.descr: A graduate introduction to theories of meaning based on the notion of truth and their application to language use.

CGSC 620.name: Research Methods in Cognitive Science
CGSC 620.descr: Cognitive science is a multi-disciplinary approach to the study of mind. Provides a practical and hands-on introduction to specific research methods from one or more disciplines (e.g. computational neuroscience modeling, experimental psychology related to cognitive science, or anthropological and linguistic research methods).

CGSC 633.name: Introduction to Acoustic Phonetics
CGSC 633.descr: Introduction to articulatory, acoustic, and perceptual characteristics of speech with emphasis on the acoustic properties of phonemes. While primarily lecture format with assigned text, a few laboratory sessions provide an introduction to computer-based methods used in instrumental studies of speech.

CGSC 642.name: Mental Representation and Memory
CGSC 642.descr: Human memory can be conceptualized in terms of representation and information storage within various interrelated mental systems. Critically evaluates research on human memory and representation within the context of major cognitive models.

CGSC 651.name: Topics in Cognitive Science
CGSC 651.restrict: May be repeated for credit when topics vary.

CGSC 655.name: Computational Linguistics
CGSC 655.descr: Natural language can be studied from a computational perspective. Course content includes aspects of formal language theory, model theory, formal grammars, computational complexity, and computational learning theory as it pertains to natural language syntax, semantics, morphology, and phonology.

CGSC 670.name: Elements of Cognitive Science
CGSC 670.descr: Introduction to the interdisciplinary study of the mind. Concentrates on the symbolic view of mind, and illustrates linguistic, psychological, anthropological, philosophical and computational approaches to language, thought, visual perception and other areas of cognition. Examines the role of representation and algorithm in theories of processing and development.

CGSC 671.name: Discovering Human Language
CGSC 671.descr: Introduction to field linguistics. Examines how languages are put together through a face-to-face encounter with an unknown language. Determine how this language - and human language in general - is constructed. Explores culture, people and even the food where the language is spoken.

CGSC 681.name: Artificial Intelligence
CGSC 681.descr: Programming techniques for problems not amenable to algorithmic solutions. Problem formulation, search strategies, state spaces, applications of logic, knowledge representation, planning and application areas.
CGSC 681.restrict: Students who received credit in CISC481, CGSC481, or CISC 681 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

CGSC 690.name: Meaning and Reference
CGSC 690.descr: Traditional scientific and philosophical issues associated with meaning and reference of language.

CGSC 696.name: Psycholinguistics
CGSC 696.descr: Study of linguistic approaches to cognition. Issues in the relation of language to thought: universals, language acquisition and theories of syntactic and semantic processing.

CGSC 848.name: Seminar in Language Development
CGSC 848.descr: Covers aspects of semantic, syntactic and phonological development through examination of current research and theory in the field. Treats educational implications of language development.

CGSC 890.name: Studies in Linguistics
CGSC 890.descr: Varying topics in linguistics, such as grammatical theory, grammatical analysis, syntax, historical-comparative linguistics, stylistics and grammar testing.
CGSC 890.restrict: May be repeated for credit when topics vary.

CMLT 207.name: Great Writers of the Western World I: 1100-1700
CMLT 207.descr: Studies writers such as Dante, Chaucer, Rabelais and Cervantes, in translation.
CMLT 207.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

CMLT 208.name: Great Writers of the Western World II: 1650-1950
CMLT 208.descr: Studies writers such as Moliere, Voltaire, Goethe, Dostoevski, Thomas Mann and Herman Hesse, in translation.
CMLT 208.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

CMLT 217.name: Introduction to Film
CMLT 217.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CMLT 218.name: Introduction to Drama
CMLT 218.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CMLT 219.name: Introduction to the Novel
CMLT 219.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CMLT 316.name: Classical Mythology: Gods, Heroes, and Monsters
CMLT 316.descr: Cosmological myths and heroic sagas in the literature and art of Greece and Rome. The influence of the mythology in later art and literature.
CMLT 316.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CMLT 317.name: Film History
CMLT 317.descr: History of American or various foreign national cinemas.
CMLT 317.restrict: May be repeated for credit when topics vary.
CMLT 317.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

CMLT 318.name: Studies in Film
CMLT 318.descr: Close study of film genres, major directors, and other topics.
CMLT 318.restrict: May be taken up to three times when topics vary.
CMLT 318.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CMLT 320.name: Varying Authors and Genres
CMLT 320.descr: Cultural, especially cross-cultural and/or interdisciplinary studies with primary emphasis on the aesthetic context of the announced topic, e.g., Nordic Saga and Myth; Courtly Love; and the European Postwar Novel.
CMLT 320.restrict: May be repeated for credit when topics vary.
CMLT 320.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CMLT 321.name: Medieval Literature and Culture
CMLT 321.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

CMLT 322.name: Topics: Classical Literature in Translation
CMLT 322.descr: Special topics in Greek and Roman culture and civilization. Particular areas and writers to be announced, e.g., ancient epic, ancient drama, Greek literature in translation.
CMLT 322.restrict: May be repeated for credit when topics vary.
CMLT 322.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CMLT 330.name: Topics: World Literatures and Cultures
CMLT 330.descr: Cultural, especially cross-cultural, study with primary emphasis on the historical development of the announced area, e.g., Nature in the Ancient World, Speculative Fiction, Transformation of a Myth. See Courses Search for topics.
CMLT 330.restrict: May be repeated three times for credit when topics vary.
CMLT 330.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

CMLT 341.name: Theatre/Drama: Classic/Medieval
CMLT 341.descr: Survey of major historical and theoretical developments in theatre practice and dramaturgy during the period. Readings in primary and secondary historical sources, major critical and theoretical texts, and representative plays of the period.
CMLT 341.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

CMLT 361.name: Studies in Literary Criticism and Theory
CMLT 361.descr: Study of problems in textual interpretation and aesthetics from the ancient world through the present, with attention to both the principal movements in critical theory and the social and philosophical contexts of interpretation. Content varies by expertise of instructor.
CMLT 361.restrict: May be taken up to three times when topics vary.

CMLT 385.name: Studies in Literary Criticism and Theory
CMLT 385.descr: Studies in selected topics in literary criticism and critical theory.
CMLT 385.restrict: May be taken up to three times when topics vary.

COMM 200.name: Topics in Communication
COMM 200.descr: Rotating topics presenting overviews of social science research on communication in various contexts including the behavior of individuals,relationships, social groups, and media in society. Emphasize theories, empirical findings, and applications of communication research in the social and behavioral sciences.
COMM 200.restrict: May be repeated two times for nine credits when topics vary.
COMM 200.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 204.name: Gender and Communication
COMM 204.descr: Deals with gender differences in communication in varied contexts, such as conflict, marriage, family, friendship, and work.
COMM 204.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 206.name: Sex, Violence, and the Media
COMM 206.descr: Examine the issues surrounding the prevalence of sex and violence in the media. Topics include free speech/press decisions and their impact, why people watch, the possible effects, and the market forces that encourage corporations to carry such content.
COMM 206.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 212.name: Public Speaking & Professional Presentation
COMM 212.descr: Includes an analysis of the types and principles of the communication inherent in the business and professional setting; a concentration upon the development of presentational skills: analyzing audiences, questioning, interviewing, researching, supporting, organizing and delivering information; an opportunity to develop and present materials within dyads, small groups and public contexts.
COMM 212.restrict: Students who have received credit in COMM 350 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

COMM 223.name: Sports, Media, and Culture
COMM 223.descr: This course examines the interrelationship of sports, media, and culture in today’s society and how that interrelationship sometimes reinforces or challenge social values. It draws on the cultural identification of class, race, and gender to identify sports values and cultural values. Drawing on theories of culture, rhetoric, and social criticism, we will examine media’s role in telling the story of sports and, in telling that story, shapes cultural values. Students will study several critical approaches to sports and public discourse and will apply those approaches to journalism, public relations, the news and popular media, and other forms of mass communication.
COMM 223.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 227.name: Family Communication
COMM 227.descr: Introduces students to the area of family communication. Gain knowledge about basic theories of family communication and learn to apply theories and research to real-world contexts.
COMM 227.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 228.name: Introduction to Organizational Communication
COMM 228.descr: The course will help students develop organizational communication knowledge, skills, and abilities to empower students to become more effective organizational members and leaders. This course is an introduction to research and theories on communication within organizations.
COMM 228.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 230.name: Communication and Interpersonal Behavior
COMM 230.descr: Introduces key principles of interpersonal communication and discusses their application across diverse contexts.
COMM 230.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 245.name: Media and Society
COMM 245.descr: The relationship between media and culture; how media affect culture (i.e., socialization and role modeling); and exploration of new forms of mass communication.
COMM 245.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 256.name: Philosophy of Communication
COMM 256.descr: This course discusses the philosophical traditions and ways of knowing that underlie and inform communication theory and scholarship.
COMM 256.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

COMM 263.name: Communicative Behavior and Culture
COMM 263.descr: Communicative processes in other cultures as well as subcultures in the US will be discussed. Students will become more mindful and aware of their own cultural patterns as well. Difficulties in cross cultural communication will also be discussed.

COMM 284.name: Gender, Culture and Digital Media
COMM 284.descr: Explores the relationship between gender, culture, and digital media.
COMM 284.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

COMM 301.name: Introduction to Communication Research Methods
COMM 301.descr: The conceptual bases of research methodology: formulating questions, designing, conducting and analyzing research.

COMM 305.name: Topics: Communication and Politics
COMM 305.descr: Topics vary and focus on significant areas of political communication with an emphasis on content, trends, processes, theories, and effects. Topics may include political entertainment, news, political advertising and campaigning, ethics, public opinion, or audience research.
COMM 305.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 306.name: Digital Technology in Politics
COMM 306.descr: Focuses on how technology influences and is used in political campaigns, public policy debates, governance, and public opinion, as well as how politics shapes technological development, processes, and policy. Special attention given to synergy among political actors, media, non-governmental organizations and citizens in shaping, consuming, and producing communication technology and policy.

COMM 309.name: Introduction to Public Relations
COMM 309.descr: Examination of the public relations process, practices and principles in various settings, including corporations, non-profit organizations, educational institutions and government. Insights are gained through case studies and interviews with public relations professionals.

COMM 311.name: Public Relations Writing
COMM 311.descr: Development of writing skills with emphasis on clarity, conciseness, color, organization and flow. Application of skills in various public relations formats (news releases, features, profiles, brochures, etc.) geared to specific audiences and appropriate channels.

COMM 313.name: Communication Principles in Advertising
COMM 313.descr: Provides a comprehensive overview of the marketing function, emphasizing integrated marketing communication. Includes historical perspective and current advertising and promotion principles and practices. Combines both individual and small team projects, such as developing an Integrated Marketing Communication campaign.

COMM 318.name: Topics in Media Communication
COMM 318.descr: Focus on introductory areas of study in mass communication.
COMM 318.restrict: May be repeated two times for nine credits when topics vary.

COMM 323.name: Topics in Journalism Production
COMM 323.descr: Experiential education involving broadcast and production topics.

COMM 324.name: Electronic Media Production
COMM 324.descr: Foundational concepts and skills to be built upon in subsequent courses in broadcast production/broadcast news sequences. Introduction to program content planning, writing for visual media, studio equipment, field equipment, and non-linear editing.
COMM 324.restrict: Serves as suggested prerequisite for COMM 326, COMM 388, and COMM 426 (News Documentary).

COMM 325.name: Studio Television Production
COMM 325.descr: Television as a mass communication media. Background, programming, production and studio procedures in educational television, broadcasting and closed circuit. Laboratory observation and practices.

COMM 326.name: Field Television Production
COMM 326.descr: Students gain practical knowledge of field television news production and utilize this knowledge to conceptualize, shoot, write, and edit videos, while working on a production deadline.

COMM 329.name: Broadcast Newswriting
COMM 329.descr: Emphasizes broadcast newswriting fundamentals and comparisons to other forms of writing. Includes news judgment, news gathering, and news editing, as well as integration of current events.
COMM 329.restrict: COMM and COMI majors not minoring in JOUR.

COMM 333.name: Social Media Management
COMM 333.descr: Explore strategic communication through social media. Experience a highly interactive classroom exploring differences between personal use and marketers’ uses of social media. Students complete multiple digital projects both in-class and out of class. Topics include marketing, public relations, audience analysis, demographics, metrics, digital engagement, interactivity, return-on-investment, scheduling, and digital monitoring through readings, videos, projects and case studies.

COMM 337.name: Topics in Political Communication
COMM 337.descr: This lecture series focuses on various thematic issues in political communication and campaign politics.
COMM 337.restrict: May be repeated twice for credit.

COMM 340.name: Politics and the Media
COMM 340.descr: Political roles of the media in socialization, political competence, agenda setting, the electoral process and political crises. Emphasis on media-political system interaction and its import in a democratic society.

COMM 341.name: Theories of Interpersonal Communication
COMM 341.descr: Survey of concepts and theories in interpersonal communication. Focuses on dyadic interaction and relationships as created, maintained, and modified through verbal and nonverbal behavior.
COMM 341.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 343.name: Topics in Interpersonal Communication
COMM 343.descr: Focuses on introductory areas of study in interpersonal communication.
COMM 343.restrict: May be repeated three times for credit when topics vary.

COMM 345.name: Legal Issues of the Mass Media
COMM 345.descr: Survey of legal issues affecting the development and performance of the mass media. The foundation of American communications law outlined through the study of First Amendment theory, its origin and development. Legal issues concerning libel, obscenity, copyright and broadcast regulation discussed.

COMM 350.name: Public Speaking
COMM 350.descr: Analyzes and applies theory and research in public speaking. Develops skills in preparation, presentation and evaluation of speeches. Includes classroom performances.

COMM 364.name: Internship
COMM 364.descr: Practical, on-the-job training in the student’s field of interest: i.e., interpersonal, mass media, public relations or organizational communication.
COMM 364.restrict: Offered in spring and fall semesters only. Open to junior and senior communication majors only. May be repeated 1 time for a maximum of 6 credits.

COMM 370.name: Theories of Media Communication
COMM 370.descr: An examination of the foundations and development of theories of mass communication. Specific areas of study include media, society and the individual, media violence, cultivation theory, personal influence, social learning theory, diffusion theory and general media effects.
COMM 370.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

COMM 388.name: Video Production Practicum
COMM 388.descr: Involves intensive work on specific productions. Includes practice in various aspects of video production: development, direction, management, production, and editing.
COMM 388.restrict: Requires permission of instructor. May be repeated for eight credits.

COMM 408.name: New Media Project Development
COMM 408.descr: Application of communication research processes to designing new media (e.g.,web sites, streaming video, electronic communication, interactive media) for aclient.  Involves conducting research for planning, developing strategies,designing prototypes, and making recommendations for implementation andevaluation.

COMM 409.name: Public Relations Campaign Planning
COMM 409.descr: Comprehensive recap of the Integrated Marketing Communication function, with anemphasis on public relations research, objectives, strategies, integratedtactics, and campaign evaluation.  Utilizes a small team “service learning”setup, wherein the teams adopt a community non-profit organization and workclosely with Board and staff members to produce and present a comprehensivepublic relations campaign plan.

COMM 413.name: Public Relations Management
COMM 413.descr: Focuses on case studies and tactics that public relations practitioners need to know in corporate, non-profit, government, education, agency, entertainment, or media settings.  Includes a strong emphasis on social media and e-portfolio development.

COMM 414.name: Topics in American Politics
COMM 414.descr: Contemporary topics in American government and politics.

COMM 417.name: Communication and the Management of Conflict
COMM 417.descr: An overview of communication and the conflict process in face-to-faceinteraction.  Emphasis on theories concerning the structure, analysis, andmanagement of conflict situations.

COMM 418.name: Advanced Topics in Media Communication
COMM 418.descr: Current directions in mass communication theory and practice including new technologies, politics, broadcast programming and research, advertising and audience responses to media content.
COMM 418.restrict: Not open to COMI majors. May be repeated three times for credit when topics vary.

COMM 421.name: Intercultural Communication
COMM 421.descr: Enhances students’ understanding of cultures, communication and intercultural communication processes. In addition, communicative strategies for improving intercultural communication is discussed.
COMM 421.restrict: Some sections offered in Madrid, Spain and Costa Rica.

COMM 423.name: Communication, Advertising, and the Consumer
COMM 423.descr: Introduction to the content of advertising, including portrayals of gender, race and sexuality. Investigate the relationship between advertising and the individual consumer, particularly what advertising cognitive effects can be and how they may result in behavioral effects.

COMM 424.name: Media Message Analysis
COMM 424.descr: Examination of methodology used to study media content and effects.  Focus on past and ongoing research in broadcast, nonbroadcast and print media.  Method of how to conduct and assess research relating to mass media.

COMM 425.name: Advanced Topics in Politics and Broadcast Journalism
COMM 425.descr: Topics vary and may include influence of crisis news on national and international politics, effectiveness of political documentaries and ethical and historical underpinnings of broadcast journalism.
COMM 425.restrict: Not open to COMI majors. May be repeated for nine credits when topics vary. When topic is News Documentary, COMM 324 suggested prerequisite.

COMM 426.name: Broadcast News Documentary
COMM 426.descr: Use the format of a news documentary to explore current issues and topics affecting society. Select a topic and spend the semester producing a documentary. Understand and perfect TV production skills, including writing, interviewing, shooting and editing.
COMM 426.restrict: May be repeated once for credit.

COMM 427.name: Broadcast News
COMM 427.descr: Communication students learn the pressures and standards of broadcast newswhile writing and producing a scheduled studio TV program.  Emphasis on writingnews for broadcast, program story-selection issues, video selection,interviewing techniques, professionalism. Students produce a weekly newsprogram in the lab.

COMM 440.name: Topics in Interpersonal Communication
COMM 440.descr: Topics vary and focus on significant areas of theory and research in interpersonal communication. Topics may include nonverbal communication, lifespan communication and communication in intimate relationships.
COMM 440.restrict: May be repeated three times for credit when topics vary.

COMM 442.name: Topics in Organizational Communication
COMM 442.descr: Focuses on significant areas of theory and research in organizational communication. Topics may include gender, communication, or interpersonal relations in organizations, such as superior/subordinate relationships.
COMM 442.restrict: May be repeated for up to nine credits when topics vary.

COMM 443.name: Communication and Emotion
COMM 443.descr: Introduces students to the role emotion plays in interpersonal communication and how communication influences our feelings. The course presents students with skill building exercises and writing assignments that are designed to put what they learn in the classroom into action in the real world.

COMM 444.name: Global Agenda
COMM 444.descr: Seminar survey of current geopolitical problems facing the US government and global news media.  Guest lecturers and practitioners in diplomacy and the international media explore the problems, US foreign policy and media influence upon both.
COMM 444.restrict: May be repeated for credit when topics vary.

COMM 446.name: Special Topics in Public Relations
COMM 446.descr: Overviews of public relations theory and practice in various contexts including research, ethics, diversity, writing, planning, execution and management.

COMM 447.name: National Agenda
COMM 447.descr: Seminar offered in conjunction with speaker series focused on current policy and political problems facing the United States. Guest lecturers, office holders and candidates, political and media practitioners explore the problems and their implications for the nation and for campaigns and decision making.
COMM 447.restrict: Students must be Juniors or Seniors and need permission of the instructor to enroll.

COMM 450.name: Media Effects
COMM 450.descr: Examines history and nature of research on effects of mass media, particularly television, in such areas as attitude change, socialization, role modeling and sex and violence.

COMM 452.name: Communication and Persuasion
COMM 452.descr: An examination of how influence is created and resisted through communication in various settings, including personal relationships, public relations, advertising and political campaigns. Emphasis on contemporary theories of persuasion and attitude change, with applications to the various content areas studied.

COMM 453.name: Health Communication
COMM 453.descr: This course examines theories and methods for studying relationships between media and health. Topics include media portrayals of health issues; public engagements with health information and technologies; and the role of media in health promotion.

COMM 454.name: Children and the Media
COMM 454.descr: Media research and theory as they relate to children. Substantive areas include children’s use and comprehension of media, content of children’s television programming, television and the family, children and advertising and the media’s contribution to social values and roles.

COMM 456.name: Communication in Organizations
COMM 456.descr: Introduction to concepts and research related to communication processes in organizational settings. Both traditional and interpretive approaches are emphasized.

COMM 458.name: Science Communication
COMM 458.descr: This course examines how scientists communicate with journalists and citizens; how news and entertainment media present science and scientists; how messages about science shape public perceptions; and how citizens engage with scientific issues.

COMM 468.name: Undergraduate Research in Communication
COMM 468.descr: Undergraduate research in area of communication conducted on or off campus, out of class, and under supervision of faculty member.
COMM 468.restrict: Open to junior and senior communication majors only. Requires permission of instructor.

COMM 476.name: Social Media and Communication
COMM 476.descr: Focus on how and why people use social media.  Various social media platforms will be explored and their effect on communicative processes will be examined.

COMM 485.name: Analysis of Face-to-Face Communication
COMM 485.descr: An examination of methods for analyzing face-to-face interaction, messageconstruction, and message interpretation.

COMM 486.name: Multimedia Literacy
COMM 486.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

COMM 490.name: Honors Capstone
COMM 490.descr: A capstone experience for Communication Honors majors.

COMM 601.name: Epistemology and Theory in Communication
COMM 601.descr: General issues in the philosophy of knowledge and science critical for the understanding of theoretical conceptions and a comprehensive survey of theories in communication.
COMM 601.restrict: Open to Communication graduate students only.

COMM 603.name: Communication Research Methods - Procedures
COMM 603.descr: Introduction to communication research methods including general research procedures, sampling, laboratory research and experimental design, survey research, field research, content analysis and longitudinal research.

COMM 604.name: Communication Research Methods - Analysis
COMM 604.descr: Introduction to the tools and techniques of data analysis in communication research including descriptive statistics, hypothesis testing, inferential statistics, as well as advanced statistical procedures.
COMM 604.restrict: Open to Communication graduate students only.

COMM 609.name: Public Relations Campaign Planning
COMM 609.descr: Comprehensive recap of the Integrated Marketing Communication function, with an emphasis on public relations research, objectives, strategies, integrated tactics, and campaign evaluation. Utilizes a small team “service learning” setup, wherein the teams adopt a community non-profit organization and work closely with Board and staff members to produce and present a comprehensive public relations campaign plan.
COMM 609.restrict: Students who received credit in COMM 721 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

COMM 610.name: Organizational Communication Theory
COMM 610.descr: An examination of major theories of organizations including functionalist paradigm; interpretive paradigm; neoclassical paradigms (classical, social exchange systems theory and structural systems theory); and modern paradigms (technological systems theory, adaptive systems theory and integrative organizational theory).
COMM 610.restrict: Open to Communication graduate students only.

COMM 613.name: Advanced Public Relations Management
COMM 613.descr: Course focuses on case studies and tactics that public relations practitioners need to know in corporate, non-profit, government, education, agency, entertainment, or media settings. Includes a strong emphasis on social media and e-portfolio development.
COMM 613.restrict: Students who received credit in COMM 727 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

COMM 617.name: Communication and the Management of Conflict
COMM 617.descr: An overview of communication and the conflict process in face-to-face interaction. Emphasis on theories concerning the structure, analysis, and management of conflict situations.

COMM 618.name: Topics in Media Communication
COMM 618.descr: Current directions in mass communication theory and research, cable television, radio and TV regulations, public policy.
COMM 618.restrict: May be repeated twice for nine credit when topics vary. Open to graduate students only.

COMM 621.name: Intercultural Communication
COMM 621.descr: Enhances students’ understanding of cultures, communication and inter-cultural communication processes. In addition, communicative strategies for improving inter-cultural communication discussed.

COMM 623.name: Communication, Advertising and the Consumer
COMM 623.descr: Introduction to the content of advertising, including portrayals of gender, race and sexuality. Investigates the relationship between advertising and the individual consumer, particularly what advertising’s cognitive effects can be and how they may result in behavioral effects.

COMM 624.name: Media Message Analysis
COMM 624.descr: Examination of methodology used to study media content and effects. Focus on past and ongoing research in broadcast, nonbroadcast and print media. The method of how to conduct and assess research relating to the mass media.

COMM 630.name: Interpersonal Communication Theory
COMM 630.descr: An examination of the theoretical orientations taken by scholars who study interpersonal relationships as well as a number of focused research areas. Of particular importance is the development of an understanding of the role of communication in creating and maintaining relationships.
COMM 630.restrict: Open to Communication graduate students only.

COMM 631.name: Politics and Entertainment
COMM 631.descr: This course considers the theoretical foundations of the link between politics and entertainment. Examined will be its causes and effects, the psychological mechanisms involved in processing entertainment content, the normative implications for citizenship, and the healthy functioning of democracy.

COMM 633.name: Topics in Political Communication
COMM 633.descr: Significant areas of theory and research in political communication. Topics may include news & politics, public opinion, or freedom of expression.

COMM 640.name: Topics in Interpersonal Communication
COMM 640.descr: Significant research, theories and literature in communication, research design and theory building.
COMM 640.restrict: May be repeated three times for credit when topics vary. Open to graduate students only.

COMM 643.name: Communication and Emotion
COMM 643.descr: Introduces students to the role emotion plays in interpersonal communication and how communication influences our feelings. The course presents students with skill building exercises and writing assignments that are designed to put what they learn in the classroom into action in the real world.

COMM 652.name: Communication and Persuasion
COMM 652.descr: An examination of how influence is created and resisted through communication in various settings, including personal relationships, public relations, advertising and political campaigns. Emphasis on contemporary theories of persuasion and attitude change, with applications to the various content areas studied.
COMM 652.restrict: Students who received credit in COMM 728 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

COMM 653.name: Health Communication
COMM 653.descr: Examines theories and methods for studying relationships between media and health such as media portrayals of health issues; public engagements with health info and technologies; and the role of media in health promotion.

COMM 654.name: Children and the Media
COMM 654.descr: Media research and theory as they relate to children. Substantive areas include children’s use and comprehension of media, content of children’s television programming, television and the family, children and advertising, and the media’s contribution to social values and roles.

COMM 656.name: Communication in Organizations
COMM 656.descr: An introduction to concepts and research related to communication processes in organizational settings. Both traditional and interpretive approaches are emphasized.

COMM 658.name: Science Communication
COMM 658.descr: Examines how scientists communicate with journalists and citizens; how news and entertainment media present science and scientists; how messages about science shape public perceptions; and how citizens engage with scientific issues.

COMM 664.name: Internship
COMM 664.descr: Provides the student with practical, on-the-job training in the field of his or her interest, i.e., interpersonal, mass media, public relations or organizational communication.

COMM 670.name: Media Theory
COMM 670.descr: Examination of theories of mass communication focusing upon media, society and the individual; sociocultural influences; the social context of the broadcast media; theories relating to effects of media violence; personal influence; social learning theory; diffusion theory; and media effects.
COMM 670.restrict: Open to Communication graduate students only.

COMM 676.name: Social Media and Communication
COMM 676.descr: Focus on how and why people use social media. Various social media platforms will be explored and their effect on communicative processes will be examined.
COMM 676.restrict: Students who received credit in COMM 732 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

COMM 685.name: Analysis of Face-to-Face Communication
COMM 685.descr: An examination of methods for analyzing face-to-face interaction, message construction, and message interpretation.

COMM 686.name: Multimedia Literacy
COMM 686.descr: Defines multimedia and discusses the impact it is having on society. Surveys applications across the curriculum and reflects on the effects of multimedia on current teaching practice. Provides a multimedia toolbox and shows how to use it to create and publish multimedia applications on the Internet. Discusses multimedia frontiers, emerging technology, and societal issues including human impact, regulation, copyright, fair use, equity, cost and universal access.

COMM 702.name: Principles of Strategic Communication
COMM 702.descr: An introduction to the world of strategic communication practice in the 21<sup>st</sup> century. Will strike a balance for students between an academic perspective, through academic research and questioning the overall role of strategic communication, and a practicing perspective, through increasing familiarity with the field.

COMM 703.name: Communication Research
COMM 703.descr: An introduction to quantitative and qualitative research methods in communication, including survey research and focus groups, to be utilized in professional and applied settings.

COMM 706.name: Communication Theory
COMM 706.descr: An exploration of major theories and perspectives on how to understand public communication and its influence on organizations, individuals, and our society.

COMM 707.name: Strategic Communication Ethics
COMM 707.descr: Familiarizes students with standards of professional ethics in a range of strategic communication environments.  Students will apply classical ethical theories to contemporary dilemmas in strategic communication.
COMM 707.restrict: Students who received credit in COMM 811 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

COMM 719.name: Reputation Management
COMM 719.descr: An examination of the role of personal reputation in an overall organization, including how corporate culture can influence a company’s reputation and how internal communications can serve as a tool. Will also examine the factors of reputational risk and the strategies behind building a reputation.

COMM 721.name: Public Relations Campaigns
COMM 721.descr: Course emphasizes public relations research, objectives, strategies, and campaign evaluation. Utilizes a service-learning approach wherein students adopt an organization to produce and present a comprehensive public relations campaign plan.
COMM 721.restrict: Students who received credit in COMM 609 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

COMM 722.name: Crisis Communication
COMM 722.descr: This course uses case studies and focuses on the six phases of crisis communication needed to successfully manage a crisis, protect an individual or organization confronted with an unexpected challenge to its reputation and communicate effectively with key stakeholders including news media.

COMM 723.name: Strategic Communication Campaigns
COMM 723.descr: An exploration of public communication campaigns, examining how the media can influence attitudes and behaviors related to issues of politics, health, or society.
COMM 723.restrict: Students who received credit in COMM 814 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

COMM 724.name: Public Relations Writing
COMM 724.descr: Students will develop professional writing skills expected of PR practitioners for a client. Writing will be based on AP style best practices, and will include calendar news release, media advisory, fact sheets, post-event news release, bios, and media pitches. Students will also develop a key messaging document for the client.

COMM 725.name: Branding
COMM 725.descr: Students learn how to develop brands, create concepts, and develop advertising campaigns. Included are how to determine appropriate media for particular campaigns, how to organize a creative department, how to create budgets and timelines, and how to research and purchase visual imagery.

COMM 727.name: PR Management
COMM 727.descr: Students use case studies and focus on strategies that public relations practitioners need to know to successfully manage issues and communicate effectively with external audiences, including news media.
COMM 727.restrict: Students who received credit in COMM 613 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

COMM 728.name: Strategic Communication and Persuasion
COMM 728.descr: An examination of how influence is created and resisted through communication in settings such as public relations, advertising, and political campaigns. There is an emphasis on contemporary theories of persuasion and attitude change.
COMM 728.restrict: Students who received credit in COMM 652 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

COMM 729.name: Topics in Public Relations
COMM 729.descr: Further examination of areas of interest within the fields of strategic communication and public relations. Topics areas explored could include organizational communication, health communication, political communication, sports communication, or advertising.

COMM 731.name: Interactive Marketing
COMM 731.descr: Explores the growing promise of mobility, the possible pitfalls of marketing in social media, and web analytics, including search engine marketing and search engine optimization. Will learn how to define their audience, establish key performance indicators, measure results, and optimize the experience for the user.

COMM 732.name: Social Media Campaigns
COMM 732.descr: An examination of social media theories and management practices. Explore how to manage a brand on social media and how to create a social media strategy for any organization or individual. Students conduct social media research, execute a social media content analysis, and develop a strategic social media plan.
COMM 732.restrict: Students who received credit in COMM 676 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

COMM 733.name: Writing for Digital Media
COMM 733.descr: Focuses on crafting and structuring written work so that it may be easily translated to various platforms and can reach the widest possible audience. Different writing processes will be used to demonstrate new ways of thinking about information.

COMM 734.name: Digital Media Content Strategy
COMM 734.descr: Discover how the use of compelling digital content can be essential to accomplishing business goals. Topics include creating content for multiple platforms, measuring success, and analyzing the competitive landscape.

COMM 735.name: Social Media Management
COMM 735.descr: Gain knowledge of social media ecosystems and social business models. Through the course work, students will analyze data to extract audience insights, develop and implement strategies, and ultimately become a skilled social media practitioner.

COMM 736.name: User Data Analytics
COMM 736.descr: Emphasizes understanding which data collection method is best for a particular context. A focus on the use and interpretation of digital analytics as well as data collection methods and basic statistics for digital sites and apps.

COMM 739.name: Topics in Digital Media
COMM 739.descr: Further examination of areas of interest within the areas of digital media. Topics areas explored could include social media, online consumer behaviors, digital political strategies, and digital health promotion.

COMM 740.name: Effective Health Communication
COMM 740.descr: Examines how communication professionals can improve communication among patients, providers, governmental agencies, and other stakeholders. A focus will be on the design, transmission, and evaluation of effective health promotional messages.

COMM 751.name: Digital Political Strategy
COMM 751.descr: Explore new political strategies in an ever increasingly networked world and learn what it takes to be a digital political strategist.

COMM 752.name: Sports Communication & Branding
COMM 752.descr: Examines how communication professionals can use sports culture to leverage brand awareness for sports organizations as well as gain a positive brand association for those companies whose identities are linked to sports. Will look at what communication strategies can be utilized to advance the brand.

COMM 753.name: Media Analytics
COMM 753.descr: Introduction to the basic concepts and uses of media analytics. Included are an exploration of data acquisition about audiences, sources of commercial data, and an overview of some of the popular analytics platforms and tools.

COMM 754.name: Communication and Leadership
COMM 754.descr: An examination of strategic communications leadership in dynamic environments, addressing: organizational models, stakeholder engagement, the role of the true trusted advisor, navigating complex corporate structures, communicating during transformation, operating globally, and foundational principles of communications leadership.

COMM 756.name: Advanced Strategic Communication Writing
COMM 756.descr: This course focuses on honing students’ abilities to create effective strategic messages across many forms of mass media and in the workplace. You will create short and long strategic messages targeting specific demographic and psychographic audiences. Specific topics include but are not limited to writing persuasive advertising copy, writing for sales and marketing, ethics, diversity and strategic writing, crisis communications writing, writing for jobs, and writing persuasive emails and subject headlines.

COMM 769.name: Strategic Communication Capstone
COMM 769.descr: Students identify a communication-related project, conduct research or design a relevant project or campaign, and deliver recommendations. Offers the opportunity to apply knowledge and skills gained through their course work.

COMM 803.name: Topics in Communication Research Methods
COMM 803.descr: Further examination of the research methodologies utilized in communication research. Topics may include experiments, surveys, or social scientifically based qualitative research methods.

COMM 808.name: Media Law and Policy
COMM 808.descr: Survey normative foundations for protecting freedom of expression, including examination of legal theorists. Review seminal U.S. case law, and administrative policies impacting free speech and press. Learn the basic methods of legal research.

COMM 811.name: Communication and Ethics
COMM 811.descr: Application of classic ethical theory to current communication ethical dilemmas, including both interpersonal and media communication. Topics will include truth and deception, privacy, and persuasion. Emphasis on digital communication.
COMM 811.restrict: Students who received credit in COMM 707 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

COMM 814.name: Communication Campaigns
COMM 814.descr: Study of public communication campaigns. Specific emphasis on the role of the media in influencing attitudes and behavior related to social, political, or health issues.
COMM 814.restrict: Students who received credit in COMM 723 are not eligible to take this course without permission.

COMM 815.name: Proseminar in Media Effects
COMM 815.descr: Covers critical issues and research in media effects. Survey of research topics and methodologies in the current literature related to the topic of interest.

COMM 832.name: Proseminar in Political Communication
COMM 832.descr: Covers critical issues and research in political communication. Survey of research topics and methodologies in the current literature related to the topic of interest.

COMM 836.name: Digital Technology in Politics
COMM 836.descr: Graduate seminar examining current directions in theory, philosophy, and practice in the intersection of technology and politics.

COMM 841.name: Proseminar in Interpersonal Communication
COMM 841.descr: Covers critical issues and research in interpersonal communication. Survey of research topics and methodologies in the current literature related to the topic of interest.

COMM 890.name: Communication Colloquium
COMM 890.descr: Feature faculty, student, and guest presentation of recent research.

COMM 964.name: Pre-Candidacy Study
COMM 964.descr: Research and readings in preparation of dissertation topic and/or qualifying examinations for doctoral students before admission to candidacy but after completion of all required course work.

CSCD 490.name: Research Practicum
CSCD 490.descr: Research experience in Communication Sciences and Disorders.

CSCD 500.name: Speech and Language Development for Clinical Management
CSCD 500.descr: This course is designed to accomplish three major goals: 1) to develop students’ ability to describe the major milestones and developmental processes of speech, language, and communication development in typical children; 2) to develop students’ ability to identify malleable influences on speech and language development in typical children, such that students have an intuition about how to alter behavior to improve speech/language in clinical settings; 3) to develop students’ ability to analyze naturalistic speech/language behaviors in typical children.
CSCD 500.restrict: Enrollment is restricted to students provisionally or fully admitted to graduate programs associated with Communication Sciences and Disorders, or the College of Health Sciences.  Does not count toward the required 60 sh for a Master’s degree in Speech-Language Pathology offered in the Department of Communication Sciences and Disorders.

CSCD 501.name: Introduction to Speech Science & Articulatory Phonetics
CSCD 501.descr: This course will provide an introduction to basic physiology, acoustics, and perception of speech and its implications for speech disorders. A portion of the course will be devoted to transcription practice using the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA).
CSCD 501.restrict: Enrollment is restricted to students provisionally or fully admitted to graduate programs associated with Communication Sciences and Disorders, or the College of Health Sciences.  Does not count toward the required 60 sh for a Master’s degree in Speech-Language Pathology offered in the Department of Communication Sciences and Disorders.

CSCD 502.name: Clinical Management of Speech-Language Pathology
CSCD 502.descr: This course is an introduction to the foundations of professional practice, assessment, treatment, and counseling in the field of speech-language pathology.
CSCD 502.restrict: Enrollment is restricted to students provisionally or fully admitted to graduate programs associated with Communication Sciences and Disorders, or the College of Health Sciences.  Does not count toward the required 60 sh for a Master’s degree in Speech-Language Pathology offered in the Department of Communication Sciences and Disorders.

CSCD 503.name: Assessment of Hearing Disorders
CSCD 503.descr: This course is designed to give students an introduction to hearing, hearing disorders, and (re)habilitation. Students will learn about hearing science and how this science relates to the assessment and treatment of hearing loss.  Students will also learn about the anatomy (structure) and physiology (function) of the auditory system.  Emphasis will be placed on learning the types, degrees and configuration of hearing loss as well as the diagnostic methods used to obtain test results.  Students will also be provided an overview of different habilitation and rehabilitation methods used as interventions for people diagnosed with hearing loss.
CSCD 503.restrict: Enrollment is restricted to students provisionally or fully admitted to graduate programs associated with Communication Sciences and Disorders, or the College of Health Sciences.  Does not count toward the required 60 sh for a Master’s degree in Speech-Language Pathology offered in the Department of Communication Sciences and Disorders.

CSCD 510.name: Neuroanatomy & Neurophysiology for Speech Language & Hearing Sciences
CSCD 510.descr: This course is an introductory neuroscience course designed to provide an in-depth overview of current principles in human behavioral neuroscience as it applies to speech-language pathology. A strong emphasis is placed on intuitively understanding the interactive nature and real-world performance features of the neuroanatomical material.
CSCD 510.restrict: Enrollment is restricted to students provisionally or fully admitted to graduate programs associated with Communication Sciences and Disorders, or the College of Health Sciences.  Does not count toward the required 60 sh for a Master’s degree in Speech-Language Pathology offered in the Department of Communication Sciences and Disorders.

CSCD 611.name: Lang Disorders in Children (Birth to 5)
CSCD 611.descr: Assessment and intervention strategies for children ages birth to 5 years with semantic, pragmatic, and morphosyntactic receptive and expressive problems deficits Language differences and disorders in various populations are covered, as well as means of assessment and intervention.

CSCD 612.name: Neurogenic Disorders: Foundation
CSCD 612.descr: Overview of acquired neurogenic language disorders and the ways in which these disorders have historically been described and explained. Course provides a review of the neural basis for communicative behaviors. Approaches to diagnosis and treatment of adult language disorders from structural to functional models are discussed.

CSCD 613.name: Speech Sound Disorders
CSCD 613.descr: Current theoretical approaches to phonetic analysis and typical speech acquisition applied to assessment and intervention with children who have articulation and phonological disorders. Practice with formal and informal articulation/phonological analysis procedures.
CSCD 613.restrict: Communication Sciences and Disorders students only.

CSCD 615.name: Cultural Humility in Clinical Practice
CSCD 615.descr: The content of this course explores how both micro- and macro-cultures influence attitudes, behavioral norms, communication, policies, and clinical practice. Students will identify and examine their own cultural norms, beliefs, and practices; discuss historic and current racism, ableism, ageism, genderism, and other forms of discriminiation along with related biases and microaggressions; discuss disparities in service access and delivery; and investigate varying approaches to advocacy and culturally responsive clinical practice.

CSCD 622.name: Lang Disorders in Children-School Age
CSCD 622.descr: A review of research in oral and written language development of school-age children; and contemporary literature on management of language disorders of school age children and adolescents. Emphasis on assessment and service delivery models; classroom management; and teaching, adaption, and implementation of IEPs.

CSCD 623.name: Neurogenic Dis of Language: Management
CSCD 623.descr: Overview of communication disorders secondary to acquired brain damage in adults; focus on aphasia, communication disorders arising from dementia, right hemisphere stroke, traumatic brain injuries; general principles of diagnosis and intervention across a variety of settings, with consideration given to the present climate of health care and functional outcomes.

CSCD 625.name: Voice and Resonance Disorders
CSCD 625.descr: Basic foundations for management of voice disorders. Techniques applicable to children and adults with disorders of voice, both functional and organic in origin.
CSCD 625.restrict: Communication Sciences and Disorders students only.

CSCD 626.name: Augmentative and Alternative Communication
CSCD 626.descr: Approaches to development of alternate modes of communication for individuals with significant motor, cognitive, and/or perceptual disabilities. System design (hardware and software) useful in building augmentative and alternative communication devices for the profoundly impaired.

CSCD 628.name: Aural Rehabilitation
CSCD 628.descr: Theory, procedures for assessment, (re)habilitation of speech, hearing, and language deficits of people with hearing impairment.
CSCD 628.restrict: Communication Sciences and Disorders students only.

CSCD 651.name: Clinical Practicum
CSCD 651.descr: Student clinicians provide intervention to communicatively impaired clients, under supervision of a certified speech language pathologists at the university speech-language- hearing clinic. Focus on planning, staffing, implementation, modification, and outcomes assessment of evaluation and intervention procedures with clients and their families.
CSCD 651.restrict: May be repeated up to ten credits.

CSCD 665.name: Counseling Skills for Speech-Language Pathologists
CSCD 665.descr: Focuses on interpersonal communication and counseling skills as a means to improve trust, rapport, treatment adherence and clinical outcomes of patients/family members in a wide range of clinical and educational environments. This course is for graduate students whose work requires them to employ counseling skills as part of service delivery. Unlike courses designed for students preparing to be psychologists, social workers, or professional counselors, this course emphasizes the boundaries and skills suitable for clinicians whose primary training is not in counseling.
CSCD 665.restrict: Communication Sciences and Disorders students only.

CSCD 710.name: Foundations of Clinical Practice III
CSCD 710.descr: A continuation of Foundations I and II and will expand students knowledge and understanding of research methods in communication sciences Focus is on scientific principles, ethical use of human participants, animal subjects and responsible conduct of research principles, and evaluation of scientific evidence. Student will begin developing their evidence-brief.
CSCD 710.restrict: Communication Sciences and Disorders students only.

CSCD 711.name: Neurogenic Disorders of Speech
CSCD 711.descr: Review of neuroanatomy and neurophysiology of brain motor systems. Characteristics of the dysarthrias and apraxia in children and adults due to congenital or acquired etiologies, including degenerative diseases. Focus on diagnosis and prognosis, and development of treatment goals.
CSCD 711.restrict: Communication Sciences and Disorders students only.

CSCD 712.name: Mngmt of Linguistically Diverse Pop.
CSCD 712.descr: Intended for students who intend to practice as bilingual speech-language pathologists. Fluency in language other than English is required. Course will review linguistic and cultural variations in language acquisition and child socialization across cultural and linguistically diverse populations. Course focus is on assessment and treatment of communication disorders in individuals from culturally and linguistically diverse groups.
CSCD 712.restrict: Communication Sciences and Disorders students only.

CSCD 713.name: Seminar: Special Topics
CSCD 713.descr: Lecture with or without laboratory component on current topics in normal aspects of communication or identification, treatment and research in speech-language pathology and audiology.
CSCD 713.restrict: May be repeated for eight credits. Communication Sciences and Disorders students only.

CSCD 714.name: Directed Research
CSCD 714.descr: Supervised laboratory experience in conducting research in communication sciences and disorders.
CSCD 714.restrict: May be repeated for three credits.

CSCD 750.name: Adv Clinical Practicum Sem
CSCD 750.descr: Course is taken concurrently with CSCD 751 and is intended to provide a forum for peer discussion of theoretical and clinical issues related to the management of patients seen in schools or health facilities. Emphasis on evidence-based practice, clinical writing, and ethical/professional issues.
CSCD 750.restrict: Open to graduate students in the MA program in SLP.

CSCD 751.name: Advanced Clinical Practicum
CSCD 751.descr: Supervised practicum in health care facility or school setting.
CSCD 751.restrict: Restricted to students in the MA in SLP. May be repeated for eight credits.

CSCD 800.name: Research Principles in Communication Sciences and Disorders
CSCD 800.descr: This course is aimed at providing coverage in philosophy and history of science, contemporary scientific philosophy and research principles. Students will also participate in initial development of their current research ideas in their domains of interest in line with these principles.
CSCD 800.restrict: Open to doctoral students in CSCD or permission of instructor.

CSCD 810.name: Advanced Seminar in Communication Sciences and Disorders
CSCD 810.restrict: Open to doctoral students in CSCD or permission of instructor.

CSCD 815.name: Communication Sciences Research Methods and Ethics
CSCD 815.descr: The purpose of this course is to provide trainees with information about research methods, research ethics and research funding.  This course provides a forum for doctoral students to present their research in progress to departmental faculty and trainees and to discuss state of the art presentations from faculty, invited speakers and postdoctoral trainees.

CSCD 816.name: Communication Sciences Research Methods and Ethics II
CSCD 816.descr: This course, part of a two-course sequence,  will provide CSCD doctoral students with in-person training in research methods and ethics that fulfils the requirements of NIH training grants.

CSCD 820.name: Independent Doctoral Study in CSCD
CSCD 820.descr: Semester long study on any topic in CSCD; topic will vary with instructor. Independent study may include readings or lab rotations.
CSCD 820.restrict: Open to doctoral students in CSCD or permission of instructor.

CSCD 860.name: Grant Writing in CSCD
CSCD 860.descr: Complete a fundable grant application. Products should be submitted for funding if the student is eligible.
CSCD 860.restrict: Course only open to doctoral students in CSCD or permission of instructor.

CSCD 895.name: Clinical Fellowship
CSCD 895.descr: Clinical experience for students seeking their certification as a speech-language pathologist.
CSCD 895.restrict: Only open to doctoral students in CSCD with permission of their Program of Study Committee.

CSCD 964.name: Pre-Candidacy Study
CSCD 964.descr: This course is used for students preparing for their prospectus or qualifying exams; most commonly for prospectus preparation.
CSCD 964.restrict: Open to doctoral students in CSCD.

CSCD 969.name: Dissertation
CSCD 969.descr: Independent dissertation research after completion of applicable course work and examinations.
CSCD 969.restrict: Only open to doctoral students in CSCD.

CISC 101.name: Principles of Computing
CISC 101.descr: Introduces students to the central ideas of computing and computer science including programs, algorithms, abstraction, the internet, and information systems. Instills ideas and practices of computational thinking and engages students in activities that show how computing and computer science change the world. Explores computing as a creative activity and empowers students to apply computational thinking to all disciplines including the arts, humanities, business, social and physical sciences, health, and entertainment.
CISC 101.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

CISC 103.name: Introduction to Computer Science with Web Applications
CISC 103.descr: Principles of computer science illustrated through programming in scripting languages such as JavaScript and VBScript. Topics include control structures, arrays, functions, and procedures. Programming projects illustrate web-based applications.
CISC 103.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

CISC 106.name: General Computer Science for Engineers
CISC 106.descr: Principles of computer science illustrated and applied through programming in a general-purpose language. Programming projects illustrate computational problems, styles, and issues that arise in engineering.
CISC 106.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

CISC 108.name: Introduction to Computer Science I
CISC 108.descr: Computing and principles of programming with an emphasis on systematic program design. Topics include functional programming, data abstraction, procedural abstraction, use of control and state, recursion, testing, and object-oriented programming concepts. Requires no prior programming experience, open to any major, but intended primarily for majors and minors in computer science or mathematics.
CISC 108.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

CISC 181.name: Introduction to Computer Science II
CISC 181.descr: Principles of computer science illustrated and applied through programming in an object oriented language. Programming projects illustrate computational problems, styles and issues that arise in computer systems development and in all application areas of computation.
CISC 181.preReq: Grade of C- or better in CISC 108 or CISC 106.
CISC 181.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

CISC 187.name: Vertically Integrated Projects I
CISC 187.descr: The Vertically-Integrated Projects (VIP) Program operates in a research and development context. Undergraduate students that join VIP teams earn academic credit for their participation in design/discovery efforts that assist faculty and graduate students with research and development issues in their areas of expertise.

CISC 210.name: Introduction to Systems Programming
CISC 210.preReq: A grade of C- or better in CISC 106 or CISC 108.

CISC 220.name: Data Structures
CISC 220.descr: Review of data type abstraction, recursion, arrays, stacks, queues, multiple stacks and linked lists. Emphasis on dynamic storage management, garbage collection, trees, graphs, tables, sorting and searching.
CISC 220.preReq: A minimum grade of C- in CISC 210.

CISC 250.name: Business Telecommunication Networks
CISC 250.descr: Examines technologies of information transmission currently utilized in the business environments and the implications of these technologies upon the development and implementation of information systems. Provides a basic background in the convergence of voice, data and video services into common digital networks. Security issues also considered.

CISC 260.name: Machine Organization and Assembly Language
CISC 260.descr: Introduction to the basics of machine organization. Programming tools and techniques at the machine and assembly levels. Assembly language programming and computer arithmetic techniques.
CISC 260.preReq: A minimum grade of C- in CISC 210.

CISC 275.name: Introduction to Software Engineering
CISC 275.descr: Object oriented software design and development through use of an object oriented programming language. Topics include team programming, design patterns, graphical user interfaces, software engineering tools (e.g., integrated development environments, version control, build management, bug tracking, automated testing).
CISC 275.preReq: Minimum grade of C- in CISC 181 and CISC 220.

CISC 287.name: Vertically Integrated Projects II
CISC 287.descr: The Vertically-Integrated Projects (VIP) Program operates in a research and development context. Undergraduate students that join VIP teams earn academic credit for their participation in design/discovery efforts that assist faculty and graduate students with research and development issues in their areas of expertise.

CISC 303.name: Automata Theory
CISC 303.descr: Automata and formal language theory. Background for advanced applications in compilers, computer networks, operating systems, and natural language processing. Finite automata and regular languages. Push down automata and context free grammars. Turing machines.
CISC 303.preReq: A minimum grade of C- in both MATH 210 and CISC 220.

CISC 304.name: Logic for Programming
CISC 304.descr: Propositional and predicate logic for general reasoning and advanced applications in knowledge representation in artificial intelligence and database, program correctness and programming semantics. Models, resolution, logic programming, and natural deduction.
CISC 304.preReq: CISC 220, MATH 210 (with minimum C- grade in both).

CISC 320.name: Introduction to Algorithms
CISC 320.descr: Design and analysis of algorithms: worst/average case analysis, proofs for correctness and performance of algorithms. Algorithmic strategies (divide and conquer, greedy methods, dynamic programming, etc.). Algorithms for searching, forming and traversal of strings, trees and graphs. Categorization of computational problems: classes P and NP. NP completeness.
CISC 320.preReq: MATH 210 and a minimum grade of C- in CISC 220.

CISC 355.name: Computers, Ethics and Society
CISC 355.restrict: Cannot be used as a technical elective for CISC or INSY majors or minors.
CISC 355.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

CISC 356.name: Intellectual Property in the Digital Age
CISC 356.descr: Explore economic, philosophical, social, and technical approaches to intellectual property (1500 BCE to present) then will research contemporary IP issues in software, entertainment, the Internet, and biotechnology.
CISC 356.restrict: Junior or Senior standing. Cannot be used as a technical elective for CISC or INSY majors or minors.
CISC 356.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

CISC 357.name: Engaging Youth in Computing
CISC 357.preReq: CISC 101 or CISC 103 or CISC 106 or CISC 108.
CISC 357.restrict: Student must have sufficient time in their schedule to visit schools weekly between 9am and 3pm. Students must pass a background check that clears them for teaching. Cannot be used as a technical elective by CISC or INSY majors.

CISC 360.name: Computer Architecture
