MMSC 650.descr: Focus on the application of the principles of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology in the understanding of human health and disease. Designed to give the students a solid foundation in the subject areas. Be useful for those preparing for health-related careers who wish to apply the knowledge of biochemistry of normal cellular function to the understanding of molecular dysfunction in human diseases.

MMSC 651.name: Cell and Tissue Culture Techniques
MMSC 651.descr: Explores basic technique training to handle in vitro cell culture as well as cellular and molecular biological techniques. You will be introduced to the procedures and the underlying scientific principles of cell culture and recombinant protein expression in a variety of cell systems including yeast, insect, and mammalian cell lines. In addition, you will learn techniques to analyze cell phenotype and function unohistochemistry, immunofluorescence, and flow cytometry.

MMSC 673.name: Advanced Clinical Chemistry and Body Fluid Analysis Practicum
MMSC 673.descr: Supervised experience in the application of laboratory theory and techniques in clinical chemistry and body fluid analysis, with discussion and synthesis of advanced topics.
MMSC 673.preReq: A grade of C- or better in MMSC 602, 612, 636, and 637.
MMSC 673.restrict: Open to MS in MLS students only.

MMSC 675.name: Advanced Clinical Hematology Practicum
MMSC 675.descr: Supervised experience in the application of laboratory procedures in hematology, with discussion and synthesis of advanced topics.
MMSC 675.preReq: A grade of C- or better in MMSC 623, MMSC 624, MMSC 633, and MMSC 634.
MMSC 675.restrict: Open to MS in MLS students only.

MMSC 677.name: Advanced Clinical Microbiology and Immunology Practicum
MMSC 677.descr: Advanced Clinical Microbiology and Immunology Practicum: Supervised experience in the application of laboratory procedures in diagnostic microbiology and immunology. With discussion and synthesis of advanced topics.
MMSC 677.preReq: A grade of C- or better in MMSC 638 and MMSC 639.
MMSC 677.restrict: Open to MS in MLS students only.

MMSC 679.name: Advanced Clinical Immunohematology Practicum
MMSC 679.descr: Advanced Clinical Immunohematology Practicum: Supervised experience in the application of laboratory procedures in immunohematology, with discussion and synthesis of advanced topics.
MMSC 679.preReq: A grade of C- or better in MMSC 620 and MMSC 621.
MMSC 679.restrict: Open to MS in MLS students only.

MMSC 690.name: Clinical and Molecular Cell Biology
MMSC 690.descr: Molecular diagnostics topics emphasize DNA, RNA and protein structure and function, including detailed review of the central dogma. Genetic topics emphasize cell development, chromosome structure and function, and disease inheritance patterns.
MMSC 690.preReq: BISC208, CHEM104 or equivalents, or by permission of the Department.

MMSC 691.name: Human Molecular Genetics
MMSC 691.descr: Molecular processes required to diagnose inherited disorders, cancer, hematological disorders, and infectious agents. Additionally, the employment of DNA identity based testing in transplantation, paternity testing and forensics will be discussed.
MMSC 691.preReq: Minimum grade of B- in MMSC 690.

MMSC 692.name: Application of Molecular Diagnostics Techniques
MMSC 692.descr: Molecular techniques commonly employed in the clinical molecular diagnostics laboratory are presented.
MMSC 692.preReq: Minimum grade of B- in MMSC 625.

MMSC 693.name: Cellular and Molecular Diagnostic Techniques
MMSC 693.descr: This laboratory course introduces students to the clinical/diagnostic applications of molecular techniques. The course will provide hands-on experience in using biochemical and imaging-based assays for molecular diagnostics. Laboratory sessions include discussion, demonstration and hands-on practice of isolation of nucleic acids from biological samples, use of hybridization-based assays in diagnostic procedures, preparation of probes, the clinical application of PCR, RT-PCR and Flow cytometry in diagnosis/prognoses of diseases. Students will be introduced to DNA and RNA sequencing platforms and liquid biopsy for analysis of genetic polymorphisms and genetic screening will be provided. An emphasis will be placed on learning existing techniques in literature as well as the most recent technological advancements. Lecture content will introduce students to the theory and practice of the molecular diagnostic laboratories as it pertains to the QC/QA and regulatory practices encountered in this sector.

MMSC 804.name: Graduate Research Seminar
MMSC 804.descr: Seminar taken after achieving candidacy, allowing graduate students to report on the progress of their research and discuss the current literature on their research focus.
MMSC 804.restrict: Open to students following successful completion of their candidacy examination.

MMSC 815.name: Contemporary Topics Research
MMSC 815.descr: Research using the various techniques and resources available to conduct experimental research and/or to measure performance improvement, test utilization, best practices and clinical outcomes.  A written research project proposal and oral defense of the proposal are required. A manuscript ready for journal submission and oral presentation are required at the conclusion of the project.
MMSC 815.restrict: Matriculated Master’s of Medical Science students only.

MMSC 868.name: Research
MMSC 868.descr: Active involvement in graduate research before completion of required coursework.

MMSC 969.name: Doctoral Dissertation
MMSC 969.descr: Independent dissertation research after completion of the Candidacy Examination.

MLSC 105.name: Introduction to Leadership I
MLSC 105.descr: Introduction to leadership principles using case studies, historical perspectives and hands-on leadership opportunities. Learn to rappell, use a map and compass, understand the basics of physical fitness and familiarize with Army traditions and ceremonies. No military obligation associated withthis course.

MLSC 106.name: Introduction to Leadership II
MLSC 106.descr: Continues to build on the basics of MLSC 105. Provides additional leadership opportunities and expands upon leadership theory. Learn basic rifle marksmanship, develop public presentation abilities and continue physical fitness development. No military obligation associated with this course.

MLSC 205.name: Basic Leadership I
MLSC 205.descr: Enhances understanding of human behavior, leadership techniques and management and planning structures. Builds leadership competencies through leadership opportunities with structured evaluations and feedback. Learn about the various branches and job opportunities in the Army. No military obligation associated with this course.

MLSC 206.name: Basic Leadership II
MLSC 206.descr: Continues to build on the basics of MLSC 205. Learn small unit tactics, how to handle up to ten people in stressful situations with feedback on performance. Further develop skills with map and compass, weapons safety and emergency first aid techniques for basic life saving. No military obligation associated with this course.

MLSC 305.name: Applied Leadership I
MLSC 305.descr: Advanced training in military leadership. One of two courses designed to prepare cadets for the ROTC Advanced Camp/Nurse Summer Training Program. Focuses on leadership development through multiple, small unit leadership opportunities and counseling. Fine tunes skills learned in the previous two years of Military Science, ROTC Basic Camp or prior military service, especially marksmanship, land navigation, drill and ceremonies and physical fitness. Commitment to military service required.

MLSC 306.name: Applied Leadership II
MLSC 306.descr: Continues to build on the basics of MLSC 305. Completes preparation for Advanced Camp/Nurse Summer Training Program and focuses on leadership at the platoon and company level. Small unit tactics and training are emphasized. Information is provided to help the student make wise decisions about military service options. Commitment to military service required.

MLSC 315.name: Leader Evaluation
MLSC 315.descr: An advanced six week off-campus, hands-on leadership education and assessment course. Real life individual and collective leadership challenges and opportunities. All expenses paid.

MLSC 365.name: Military History Studies
MLSC 365.descr: Selected topics in American military history, current military trends and future military requirements.

MLSC 405.name: Advanced Leadership I
MLSC 405.descr: Prepares cadets for commissioning by refining professional skills and leadership ability. Students assigned leadership positions and function as commanders and staff officers in planning and executing cadet battalion activities. Focuses on technical skills needed to accomplish assigned missions and other topics which expand cadet knowledge of Army systems and procedures. Commitment to military service required.

MLSC 406.name: Advanced Leadership II
MLSC 406.descr: Builds on leadership skills from MLSC 405 and helps complete the transition from cadet to Lieutenant. Cadets are assigned new leadership positions to broaden their leadership experience. Focuses on officer professional development subjects needed to manage a military career and personal affairs. Commitment to military service required.

MSST 203.name: Introduction to Museums
MSST 203.descr: Introduction to the history, operations and future of museums, historic sites, archives and related cultural organizations. Examines collecting and collection management, conservation of collections, exhibition development, public programs and museum education, and digital outreach. Museum careers and volunteer engagement are explored.
MSST 203.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

MSST 385.name: History Behind the Scenes
MSST 385.descr: Explore how history is presented to public audiences in a variety of settings (museums and historic sites, archives, public gardens) and media (documentaries, digital media). Field trips and discussion with professionals. Topics may also include art history, historical anthropology and natural history.
MSST 385.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

MSST 401.name: Curatorship and Collections Management
MSST 401.descr: Curatorship and Collections Management introduces students to the ethical, legal and practical considerations associated with developing, recording, maintaining and displaying collections in museums, archives and related collecting institutions. History, art, ethnographic, science and natural history collections are discussed. Students receive hands-on experience in collection management and care.

MSST 402.name: Archives and Paper Collections: Curatorship and Management
MSST 402.descr: Introduction to theory and best practices in collecting and management of archives and paper collections in museums, archives and other collecting institutions. Topics include collecting, processing and access, and care of manuscripts, paper ephemera, photographs and other paper formats. Combines classroom instruction, demonstrations and field trips with group and individual hands-on projects.

MSST 407.name: Museum Education and Interpretation
MSST 407.descr: Introduces theory, practices, evaluation methods and administration of learning activities in museum environments. Class discussion and field trips to area museums and historic sites lead into group projects developing lessons and programs for both school-age and adult visitors.

MSST 410.name: Exhibitions
MSST 410.descr: Introduction to the process of exhibition development, from proposal to installation. Topics may include how visitors use exhibitions; writing exhibition proposals; object and image selection; scripting; panel design; case design; object preparation; educational materials; and evaluation. When an appropriate project is identified, students will work in teams to create and install a small exhibition.
MSST 410.restrict: Priority given to students registered for the Museum Studies Minor.

MSST 411.name: Topics in Museum Administration
MSST 411.descr: Taught by leaders in the field of arts and culture administraion, Topics in Museum Administration offers intensive study blending discussion and hands-on work in such topics as fundraising, grant writing, database management, budgeting and budget analysis, and governance and board leadership.  Students make take the course more than once with different topics.

MSST 413.name: The Digital Museum
MSST 413.descr: Examines the use of technology in museums with an emphasis on communication strategies for museum exhibitions and off-site learning. Examines the use of digital technology in museums. Topics may include best practices in museum web design, virtual exhibitions, digital communication strategies, digital image processing, publicly-accessible collection databases, game design and animation for educational use, and application design.
MSST 413.restrict: Permission of instructor. Not open to freshmen.

MSST 447.name: Curating Hidden Collections & the Black Archive
MSST 447.descr: Thematic, collections-based study of African American collections and their digital curation. Includes the study of archival and theoretical challenges in making the collection and others like it available to the public through various curated platforms.
MSST 447.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MSST 462.name: Professional Development
MSST 462.descr: Preparation for application to graduate training or for professional employment in museums or related cultural organizations. Topics include preparation of resumes or curriculum vitae; creating an e-portfolio; preparation of application essays and cover letters; and interview coaching.

MSST 463.name: Archaeology, Engagement, Heritage
MSST 463.descr: Examines archaeology and heritage in cultural resource management, museum and historic site interpretation, and public history. Addresses archaeological philosophy, practice, and pedagogy. Engages the academic-public discourse relating to the construction, dissemination, and contesting of archaeological knowledge in seminar and practical project experience at an agency, research center, museum, or community organization.
MSST 463.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

MSST 464.name: Museum Studies Internship
MSST 464.descr: Internship in physical or digital exhibitions, education, public programs, community engagement, collections management, fundraising, marketing, or other administrative or service functions of museums, archives, or other organizations focused on interpreting evidence for non-scholarly audiences. Placement must be approved by Museum Studies Director or Coordinator.  May include group placements for special projects.

MSST 600.name: Introduction to Museums: History and Professional Practice
MSST 600.descr: Core course for the Museum Studies Certificate Program. Introduction to the history of museums and examines selected current issues in museum professional practice. Content may offer discussion of issues in collecting and exhibition practice, education and audience development, evolving professional ethics, and museum governance.
MSST 600.restrict: Open to graduate students only. Students who are not seeking the Museum Studies Certificate must have the instructor’s permission to register.

MSST 601.name: Curatorship and Collections Management
MSST 601.descr: Theory and practice in curatorial collecting and collections management. Topics include the ethical framework and legal requirements of collecting by not-for-profit organizations; research techniques to support collecting and collection documentation; the legal requirements and best practices of collections administration; care and handling requirements; and decision making for conservation. Combines classroom instruction, demonstrations and field trips with “hands on” projects.

MSST 602.name: Curatorship and Management of Archives and Paper Collections
MSST 602.descr: An introduction to theory and best practices in collecting and management of archives and paper collections, including collecting, processing and access, and care. Combines classroom instruction, demonstrations and field trips with “hands on” projects.

MSST 603.name: The Digital Museum
MSST 603.descr: Examines the use of digital technology in museums.  Topics may include best practices in museum web design, virtual exhibitions, digital communication strategies, digital imageprocessing, publicly-accessible collection databases, game design and animation for educational use, and application design.

MSST 605.name: Historical Properties
MSST 605.descr: Administration and interpretation of historical properties, including historic site surveys, preservation research, building restoration, conservation techniques and the establishment and attainment of interpretive objectives. Field trips to area historic sites. Combines classroom instruction and work projects at area historic sites.

MSST 606.name: Issues in American Material Culture
MSST 606.descr: Studies major themes in American material culture of the 17th, 18th or 19th centuries. Topics vary.

MSST 607.name: Museum Education and Interpretation
MSST 607.descr: The theory, strategies, practices, evaluation and administration of learning in a museum environment with emphasis on interpretation of collections through a variety of instructional means.  Lectures, discussions, field trips, program planning, curriculum development, proposal writing, audience studies, practice teaching and special project work with area museums.

MSST 610.name: Exhibitions
MSST 610.descr: Best practices in planning, scripting, designing, fabricating, and evaluating exhibitions in museums, libraries, and related venues.

MSST 611.name: Topics in Museum Administration
MSST 611.descr: Topics in Museum Administration is a group of short courses on such topics as museum boards and governance, financial management, database management, fundraising and grant writing.  Each course is taught be a professional in the field.  Students may repeat MSST 611 with different topics.

MSST 615.name: Exhibition and Interpretation of Material Culture
MSST 615.descr: Practicum at Winterthur in exhibiting & interpreting American material culture in a global context, centering on objects selected from Winterthur collections. Topics include: exhibition preparation, installation, programming, fundraising, marketing.

MSST 629.name: Historic Preservation Theory and Practice
MSST 629.descr: Analysis of the theory underlying historic preservation in the United States and globally, including its history and evolution over time. Examines the impact of preservation laws and public policies, and the strategies and regulations for identifying significant structures, sites, and cultural heritage worthy of preservation.

MSST 647.name: Curating Hidden Collections & the Black Archive
MSST 647.descr: Thematic, collections-based study of African American collections and their digital curation. Includes the study of archival and theoretical challenges in making the collection and others like it available to the public through various curated platforms.

MSST 654.name: Architecture of Everyday Life
MSST 654.descr: Understanding and interpreting everyday buildings and landscapes by seeing the built environment through a physical lens (material, construction, style and plan) and social lens (gender, class, race) and from the perspective of multiple disciplines.

MSST 663.name: Archeology, Engagement, Heritage
MSST 663.descr: Examines archaeology and heritage in cultural resource management, museum and historic site interpretation, and public history. Addresses archaeological philosophy, practice, and pedagogy. Engages the academic-public discourse relating to the construction, dissemination, and contesting of archaeological knowledge in seminar and practical project experience at an agency, research center, museum, or community organization.

MSST 674.name: Studies in Print and Material
MSST 674.descr: Variable content. Survey of major themes in print and material culture studies, with exploration of research methods, theoretical approaches, and curatorial practices.

MSST 804.name: Museum Internship
MSST 804.descr: Internship practice in administration, collections management, exhibition and interpretation at museums and related institutions. Students spend ten full weeks, or the equivalent, at the University museum, Winterthur Museum, Hagley Museum, Longwood Gardens or other acceptable institution.
MSST 804.restrict: Open to graduate students only. Requires at least one semester course in museum studies and permission of instructor.

MUSC 100.name: Recital Attendance
MUSC 100.descr: A recital experience; see Department of Music Student Handbook for details.
MUSC 100.restrict: May be repeated. Open to music majors only. Offered in fall and spring semesters. .

MUSC 101.name: Appreciation of Music
MUSC 101.descr: Introduction to Western music literature through a nontechnical presentation of various musical styles and forms.
MUSC 101.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 102.name: Appreciation of Music II
MUSC 102.descr: Music literature through a nontechnical presentation of various musical styles and forms. Continuation of MUSC101 with emphasis on the larger forms - symphonies, operas, oratorios, concertos - and the 20th century.
MUSC 102.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 105.name: Fundamentals of Music I
MUSC 105.descr: Introduction into the elements of music theory including ear training, music reading and harmony with keyboard application.
MUSC 105.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 106.name: Computational Thinking in Music
MUSC 106.descr: Learn concepts and tools for thinking about information, processes, problems, and systems relevant to creating, hearing, and analyzing music. Computational principles such as programming, data, algorithms, and abstraction will be used to conceptualize, model, and communicate musical processes and design, and how humans interact with music. Requires no formal training in music or computer science. Blend creative and computational thinking to complete individual and collaborative projects.
MUSC 106.breadth: University: Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology; A&S: GROUP D: A&S Math, Nat Sci & Technology

MUSC 107.name: History of Rock
MUSC 107.descr: The study of various styles of rock music. Introduction to folk, country, blues, and jazz as predecessors to rock. Intended for the non-music major. No music reading skills required.
MUSC 107.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

MUSC 112.name: University Strings
MUSC 112.descr: A music ensemble for string instrument players who are not in Symphony Orchestra. No audition required. One performance per semester. May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 112.restrict: Students may enroll for 0-credit only if they have reached the 17-credit limit. Music majors and minors must be enrolled for credit in at least one departmentally approved ensemble during each semester of private study.
MUSC 112.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 119.name: Collegiate Band
MUSC 119.descr: Collegiate Band is an ensemble designed for non-music majors and music majors playing secondary instruments to develop as musicians in a concert setting. Students will learn fundamental ensemble playing techniques through performance of standard and modern wind band literature.
MUSC 119.restrict: May be repeated for up to eight credits.
MUSC 119.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 120.name: Pep Band
MUSC 120.descr: Attends all home basketball games performing a variety of pop, rock and jazz selections. Performs at select games during Winter Session. Attendance at these games is mandatory.
MUSC 120.restrict: Requires audition and may be repeated for credit. Offered in spring semester only. Students may sign up for 0-credit only if they have reached the 17-credit limit. Music majors and minors must be enrolled for credit in at least one departmentally approved ensemble during each semester of private study.
MUSC 120.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 122.name: History of Film Music
MUSC 122.descr: This course will examine the history of music in film from its beginnings at the turn of the Twentieth century to present day. It will trace the evolution of major composers and their influences, as well as provide students with a detailed overview of cinema’s diverse history. The class is historical survey which also incorporates elements of a seminar.
MUSC 122.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 123.name: Steel Band
MUSC 123.descr: Teaches music and theory through rote learning, reading, and improvisation to students with no musical training. Students perform in a traditional Caribbean Steel Drum Band.
MUSC 123.restrict: Students may sign up for 0-credit only if they have reached the 17-credit limit.
MUSC 123.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 124.name: Steel Band: Advanced Ensemble
MUSC 124.descr: Traditional Caribbean Steel Drum ensemble. Students rehearse and perform music of the Caribbean tradition.
MUSC 124.restrict: Permission of instructor students may sign up for 0-credit only if they have reached the 17-credit limit. Music majors and minors must be enrolled for credit in at least one departmentally approved ensemble during each semester of private study. May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 124.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 130.name: Alexander Technique: The Art of Living
MUSC 130.descr: Experience and learn to co-operate with your design for natural co-ordination, bringing more ease, and presence into your life. We take this practice first into everyday activities, and then into the expressive arts and other specialized skills.
MUSC 130.restrict: May be repeated three times for credit.

MUSC 150.name: Freshman Honors Private Study
MUSC 150.descr: Private study for qualified freshman honors students. The student adds to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, or an orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class.
MUSC 150.restrict: Restricted to freshman honors students only. May be repeated for credit. Offered in fall and spring semesters. Must be enrolled in a departmentally approved ensemble.
MUSC 150.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 151.name: Private Study for Bachelor of Music I
MUSC 151.descr: Private study for freshman Bachelor of Music students. The student will add to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, or an orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class.
MUSC 151.preReq: Audition and acceptance into Bachelor of Music program.
MUSC 151.restrict: For Bachelor of Music students only. Offered in fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 152.name: Private Study for Bachelor of Music II
MUSC 152.descr: Continuing private study for freshman bachelor of music students.  The studentadds to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, oran orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class.
MUSC 152.preReq: MUSC 151 with a grade of C- or better.
MUSC 152.restrict: For bachelor of music students only. Offered in fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 153.name: Private Study for Bachelor of Arts and Minors I
MUSC 153.descr: Private study for Bachelor of Arts (music) students and Music Minors. The student will add to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ,voice, or an orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class.
MUSC 153.preReq: Audition and acceptance into Bachelor of Arts (Music) or Music Minor.
MUSC 153.restrict: For Bachelor of Arts (music) students and Music Minors only. Offered in fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 154.name: Private Study for Music Bachelor of Arts and Minors II
MUSC 154.descr: Continuing private study for bachelor of arts (music) students and musicminors. The student adds to the course title the branch of study elected:piano, organ, voice, or an orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studioclass.
MUSC 154.preReq: MUSC 153 with a grade of C- or better.
MUSC 154.restrict: For bachelor of arts (music) students and music minors only. Offered in fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 155.name: Private Study for Secondary and Merit I
MUSC 155.descr: Private study for music majors pursuing a secondary area, and qualifiedstudents not enrolled in a music degree program. Student adds to course titlethe branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, or orchestral instrument.Includes a one-hour studio class. May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 155.restrict: Requires audition and permission of instructor. Offered in fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 171.name: Diction: English and Italian
MUSC 171.descr: Study of pronunciation rules for singing in English and Italian. Includes practicum.
MUSC 171.restrict: Restricted to applied music/voice majors. Offered in fall semester only.

MUSC 174.name: Directing School Choirs
MUSC 174.descr: Methods of class vocal instruction and repertoire rehearsal in school choral programs for nonvocal music majors.
MUSC 174.preReq: Requires one semester of University vocal experience.

MUSC 175.name: Class Piano: Elementary I
MUSC 175.descr: Beginning piano primarily for the vocal or instrumental music major. Basic techniques, reading, transposition and playing by ear.
MUSC 175.restrict: Preference for enrollment given to music majors and minors. Nonmusic majors require permission of instructor. Offered in fall semester only.

MUSC 176.name: Class Piano: Elementary II
MUSC 176.descr: A continuation of MUSC 175. Scale and arpeggio playing, keyboard harmony, repertory of pieces appropriate to technical ability.
MUSC 176.preReq: MUSC 175 with grade of C- or better.
MUSC 176.restrict: Preference for enrollment given to music majors and minors. Nonmusic majors require permission of instructor. Offered in spring semester only.

MUSC 177.name: Class Guitar I
MUSC 177.descr: Introduction to the fundamentals of guitar technique and note reading for non-music majors. Topics include guitar history, repertoire, scales and exercises with a emphasis on classical as well as folk music. Music Education majors may also find this course particularly useful for classroom teaching.
MUSC 177.restrict: Offered in fall and spring semesters.
MUSC 177.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 178.name: Jazz Harmony at the Keyboard
MUSC 178.descr: This course will prepare students to play functional jazz piano. Students  study voicing chords, voice leading in common jazz and popular progressions, arranging for solo piano, bassline construction and improvisation.

MUSC 181.name: Private Study for Applied Jazz Styles and Techniques
MUSC 181.descr: Private studio instruction covering improvisational techniques and interpretation used in jazz performance. Examines a cross-section of styles and repertoire.
MUSC 181.restrict: Requires audition and permission of instructor. Offered in fall and spring semesters.
MUSC 181.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 182.name: Private Study for Applied Jazz Styles and Techniques
MUSC 182.descr: Private studio instruction covering improvisational techniques and interpretation used in jazz performance. Examines a cross-section of styles and repertoire.
MUSC 182.preReq: MUSC 181 with a grade of C- or better.
MUSC 182.restrict: Requires permission of instructor. Offered in spring and fall semesters.
MUSC 182.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 183.name: Jazz Improvisation
MUSC 183.descr: This course will develop skills for improvisation on standard jazz forms such as blues, rhythm changes, modal structures and other standard songs. Emphasis will be placed on the application of chord/scale relationships, transcription and analysis of jazz solos, and aural skills.

MUSC 184.name: Music Fundamentals: Theory and Fluency
MUSC 184.descr: Build fundamental knowledge to enable success in the music theory sequence. Students learning outcomes include achieving fluency in identifying and spelling notes, scales, key signatures, intervals, and triads. Students must earn passing scores in each outcome to earn an overall passing grade.
MUSC 184.restrict: This is a remedial course and does not earn credit towards a degree.

MUSC 185.name: Aural Skills I
MUSC 185.descr: Techniques of sight singing and music reading skills. Development of ability in aural recognition of melody, harmony and rhythm.
MUSC 185.preReq: Must take department music theory placement test.

MUSC 186.name: Aural Skills II
MUSC 186.descr: Techniques of sight singing and music reading skills. Development of ability in the aural recognition of melody, harmony and rhythm.
MUSC 186.preReq: MUSC 185 with grade of C- or better.
MUSC 186.restrict: Open to music majors and minors. Offered in spring semester only.

MUSC 193.name: Sight Reading at the Keyboard I
MUSC 193.descr: Techniques for improving coordination and musical comprehension when playing from sight at the keyboard.
MUSC 193.restrict: For keyboard majors. Offered in fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 194.name: Sight Reading at the Keyboard II
MUSC 194.preReq: MUSC 193 with a grade of C- or better.
MUSC 194.restrict: For keyboard majors. Offered in fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 195.name: Harmony I
MUSC 195.descr: Review of music fundamentals. Diatonic harmony including part-writing with keyboard application. Chord structures and functional relationships. Basic melodic and contrapuntal compositional techniques. Writing, playing and analysis.
MUSC 195.preReq: MUSC 185 with grade of C- or better.
MUSC 195.restrict: Must pass department Music Theory Placement Test or Theory Review Class. Offered spring only.

MUSC 196.name: Harmony II
MUSC 196.descr: Continuation of harmony: diatonic through chromatic harmony with keyboard application. Chord structures and functional relationships. Basic melodic and contrapuntal compositional techniques. Writing, playing and analysis.
MUSC 196.preReq: MUSC 186 and MUSC 195 with grades of C- or better.
MUSC 196.restrict: Open only to music majors and minors. Offered fall only.

MUSC 204.name: Global Pop Unbound
MUSC 204.descr: Thanks to Youtube, Spotify, iTunes, and other web-­‐based music streams, our current listening experience of, and taste in, popular music is boundless, from our own local music to the popular music of other societies and other nations. This course, focuses on a survey of popular music in selected countries, from Africa to Latin America, from Asia to northern Europe.
MUSC 204.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 205.name: Music of the World
MUSC 205.descr: Survey of non-Western world musical cultures utilizing textbook, reprinted reserve articles, films and in-class performance/demonstrations. Goal is the understanding and appreciation of various world musics.
MUSC 205.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

MUSC 206.name: Music of China, Korea and Japan
MUSC 206.descr: Systematically examines the origin and historical development of the musicalcultures of the Far East.  Studies how the musical and cultural influence ofChinese musical culture has had an enormous impact on the development of suchcultures in Korea and Japan.
MUSC 206.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

MUSC 207.name: History of Jazz
MUSC 207.descr: Chronological study of the style changes in jazz from the late 19th century to the present. Emphasis on the sociological, economic and technological influences of the period and on the principal personalities who have been primarily responsible for change.
MUSC 207.restrict: Offered in even numbered years, fall semester only.
MUSC 207.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

MUSC 208.name: Queer Perspectives on Popular Music
MUSC 208.descr: A survey of twentieth-century popular music in the United States from the perspective of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgendered, and queer artists and listeners, drawing upon the fields of musicology and queer, feminist, and critical race studies.
MUSC 208.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

MUSC 209.name: Instrumental Methods for General/Choral Students I
MUSC 209.descr: Development of pedagogy and performance skills.

MUSC 210.name: Instrumental Methods for General/Choral Students II
MUSC 210.descr: Development of pedagogy and performance skills.

MUSC 211.name: Music, History, and Ideas
MUSC 211.descr: Examines methods, materials, and interdisciplinary approaches used in the study of music through the discussion and analysis of a broad repertoire of works that spans historical eras, styles, and global cultures. Class is organized around broad historical topics (historiography, performance practice, notation, authorship, etc.).
MUSC 211.preReq: MUSC 195 and MUSC 186 with a grade of C- or better

MUSC 214.name: Stringed Instruments I
MUSC 214.descr: Development of pedagogy and performance skills.
MUSC 214.restrict: Open only to music education and theory/composition majors.

MUSC 215.name: Brass Instruments I
MUSC 215.descr: Development of pedagogy and performance skills.
MUSC 215.restrict: Open only to music education and theory/composition majors.

MUSC 216.name: Brass Instruments II
MUSC 216.descr: Advanced development of pedagogy and performance skills.
MUSC 216.preReq: MUSC 215 with a grade of C- or better.
MUSC 216.restrict: Open only to music education and theory/composition majors.

MUSC 217.name: Woodwind Instruments I
MUSC 217.descr: Development of pedagogy and performance skills.
MUSC 217.restrict: Open only to music education and theory/composition majors.

MUSC 218.name: Woodwind Instruments II
MUSC 218.descr: Advanced development of pedagogy and performance skills.
MUSC 218.preReq: MUSC 217 with a grade of C- or better.
MUSC 218.restrict: Open only to music education and theory/composition majors.

MUSC 219.name: Percussion Instruments
MUSC 219.descr: Development of pedagogy and performance skills.
MUSC 219.restrict: Open only to music education and theory/composition majors.

MUSC 220.name: Marching Band Techniques
MUSC 220.descr: Focuses on designing and charting a show of the complete contemporary marchingband. Overview of history and development of the marching band, as well as “hands-on” sessions in marching percussion and color guard.
MUSC 220.preReq: MUSC 470 with a grade of C- or better.

MUSC 221.name: Marching Percussion Techniques
MUSC 221.descr: Focuses on advancing skills on the marching snare drum, multi-tenors, bass drum, cymbals or front ensemble. Emphasizes techniques through an opportunity to learn basic arranging skills. Open to students of all skill levels.
MUSC 221.restrict: Offered spring semester only. May be repeated for credit.

MUSC 222.name: Stringed Instruments II
MUSC 222.descr: Advanced development of pedagogy and performance skills.
MUSC 222.restrict: Open only to music education and theory/composition majors.

MUSC 223.name: Steel Band Traditions and Practice
MUSC 223.descr: Teaches music and theory through rote learning, reading, and improvisation to students with no musical training.  Students perform in a traditional Caribbean Steel Drum Band.  In addition students make weekly visits to the “panyards” where the many steel bands of Trinidad and Tobago rehearse for the Panorama Competition.

MUSC 224.name: London and the Movie Soundtrack
MUSC 224.descr: Examine the role music plays in film with a particular concentration on the scores recorded by the London Symphony Orchestra, London Philharmonic Orchestra, and the Philharmonia Orchestra. Includes a brief overview of the evolution of film music, an exploration of select composers and compositional style, as well as recording session techniques. We will visit the archives of these three orchestras, attend open rehearsals, performances, screen select films and hear from a variety of experts on music and film.
MUSC 224.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 225.name: Jewish Music
MUSC 225.descr: Designed to present a study of the Jewish music as it has evolved from biblical era through the contemporary period. Encompass the numerous cultures and lands that the Jewish people have found themselves residing from Australia to America, Brazil to Bombay and many more. The course will look at the formal presentation of music in religious life, the creative presentation in social and religious life, and to the languages, styles, and cross-fertilization that happens when civilizations combine. From the synagogue to the street, the school room and bedroom, music is one lens through which we can understand Jewish life.
MUSC 225.breadth: University: ; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 226.name: London: City of Symphonies
MUSC 226.descr: Examines the fertile arts environment in London that led to the development of one of the world’s greatest symphonic traditions. Dating back to the late eighteenth century and the rise of an established public concert series to the present day symphonic tradition, London boasts a diversity of orchestral opportunity that is unparalleled. After a brief examination of the historical roots, this class will focus on the contemporary orchestral music scene. We will visit the archives of major orchestras, attend open rehearsals, performances and hear from a variety of experts including musicians and administrators.
MUSC 226.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

MUSC 227.name: Popular Music of the Global South
MUSC 227.descr: Introduces students to popular musical styles that connect the transatlantic diaspora and inform the diversity of music genres from the Global South; introduces music as a cultural device and an aspect of political and sociological struggles for democracy and a cultural space for racial integration.
MUSC 227.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 228.name: From Soul to Hip Hop
MUSC 228.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities (ART & HUM); A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 231.name: Orchestration
MUSC 231.descr: Advanced orchestral and band arranging; review of instrumental ranges and colors; scoring for small ensembles; special problems in scoring accompaniments. Final arrangement performed by a University Ensemble.

MUSC 241.name: Accompanying Chamber Music: Piano
MUSC 241.descr: Accompanying vocalists and instrumentalists in the performance of chamber music with keyboard.
MUSC 241.restrict: Offered fall and spring semesters. May be taken 4 times for credit.
MUSC 241.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 251.name: Private Study for Bachelor of Music III
MUSC 251.descr: Continuing private study for sophomore bachelor of music students.  The studentadds to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, oran orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class.
MUSC 251.preReq: MUSC 152 with a grade of C- or better.
MUSC 251.restrict: For bachelor of music students only. Offered fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 252.name: Private Study for Bachelor of Music IV
MUSC 252.descr: Continuing private study for sophomore bachelor of music students. The student adds to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, or an orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class. In lieu of a jury, the student  performs a Sophomore Review which must be passed in order to continue on to junior-level private study (see student handbook for details).
MUSC 252.preReq: MUSC 251 with a grade of C- or better.
MUSC 252.restrict: For bachelor of music students only. Offered fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 253.name: Private Study for Bachelor of Arts and Minors III
MUSC 253.descr: Continuing private study for bachelor of arts (music) students and musicminors.  The student adds to the course title the branch of study elected:piano, organ, voice, or an orchestral instrument.  Includes a one-hour studioclass.
MUSC 253.preReq: MUSC 154 with a grade of C- or better.
MUSC 253.restrict: For bachelor of arts (music) students and music minors only. Offered fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 254.name: Private Study for Music Bachelor of Arts and Minors IV
MUSC 254.descr: Continuing private study for bachelor of arts (music) students and musicminors.  The student adds to the course title the branch of study elected:piano, organ, voice, or an orchestral instrument.  Includes a one-hour studioclass.
MUSC 254.preReq: MUSC 253 with a grade of C- or better.
MUSC 254.restrict: For bachelor of arts (music) students and music minors only. Offered fall and spring semesters only.

MUSC 271.name: Diction: German
MUSC 271.descr: A study of pronunciation rules for singing in German. Includes practicum.
MUSC 271.preReq: MUSC 171 with a grade of C- or better.

MUSC 272.name: Diction: French
MUSC 272.descr: A study of pronunciation rules for singing in French. Includes practicum.
MUSC 272.preReq: MUSC 171 with a grade of C- or better.

MUSC 275.name: Class Piano: Intermediate I
MUSC 275.descr: Piano techniques applicable to the levels and needs of the students; a continuation of reading and transposition; and improvisation and repertory of grade two pieces.
MUSC 275.preReq: MUSC 176 with grade of C- or better.
MUSC 275.restrict: Restricted to music majors and minors, or by permission of instructor. Offered fall semester only.

MUSC 276.name: Class Piano: Intermediate II
MUSC 276.preReq: MUSC 275 with a grade of C- or better.
MUSC 276.restrict: Restricted to music majors and minors, or by permission of instructor. Offered spring semester only.

MUSC 281.name: Private Study for Applied Jazz Styles and Techniques I
MUSC 281.descr: Private studio instruction covering improvisational techniques and interpretation used in jazz performance. Examines a cross-section of styles and repertoire.
MUSC 281.preReq: MUSC 181 with a grade of C- or better.
MUSC 281.restrict: Requires permission of instructor. Offered fall and spring semesters.
MUSC 281.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 282.name: Private Study for Applied Jazz Styles and Techniques II
MUSC 282.descr: Private studio instruction covering improvisational techniques and interpretations used in jazz performance. Examines a cross-section of styles and repertoire.
MUSC 282.preReq: MUSC 281 with a grade of C- or better.
MUSC 282.restrict: Requires audition. Offered fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 285.name: Advanced Aural Skills I
MUSC 285.preReq: MUSC 186 and MUSC 195 with grades of C- or better.
MUSC 285.restrict: Open to music majors and minors, or by permission of instructor. Offered fall semester only.

MUSC 286.name: Advanced Aural Skills II
MUSC 286.descr: Continuation of MUSC 185, MUSC 186 and MUSC 285.
MUSC 286.preReq: MUSC 285 and MUSC 196 with grades of C- or better.
MUSC 286.restrict: Open to music majors and minors, or by permission of instructor. Offered spring semester only.

MUSC 293.name: Jazz Theory and Improvisation I
MUSC 293.descr: This course develops skills for improvising on various chord progressions common in jazz. Students will put concepts of jazz theory into practice. Chord/scale relationships for creating melodies in the harmony, melodic lines that clearly bring out chord progressions and compositional ideas of melodic development will be studied. Transcription and analysis of historically significant jazz solos will provide a deeper conception of the jazz language. Piano voicings, bass line construction, basic drum skills will be explored in this class.
MUSC 293.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 294.name: Jazz Theory and Improvisation II
MUSC 294.descr: This course continues the study of jazz theory and improvisation by developing skills for improvising on more advanced chord progressions in jazz. Students will put concepts of jazz theory into practice. Chord/scale relationships for creating melodies in the harmony, melodic lines that clearly bring out chord progressions and compositional ideas of melodic development will be studied. Transcription and analysis of historically significant jazz solos will provide a deeper conception of the jazz language. Piano voicings, bass line construction, basic drum skills will be explored in this class.

MUSC 295.name: Advanced Harmony I
MUSC 295.descr: Review of chromatic harmony. Study, writing and analysis of 18th century counterpoint. Introduction to instrumentation. Introduction to form and analysis. Eighteenth and nineteenth century harmony, techniques and styles. Original compositions.
MUSC 295.preReq: MUSC 285 and MUSC 196 with grades of C- or better.
MUSC 295.restrict: Open to music majors and minors, or by permission of instructor. Offered spring semester only.

MUSC 296.name: Advanced Harmony II
MUSC 296.descr: Continuation of MUSC 295. Study of late 19th and 20th century harmony, techniques and styles. Continuation of instrumentation. Original compositions.
MUSC 296.preReq: MUSC 286 and MUSC 295 with grades of C- or better.
MUSC 296.restrict: Open to music majors and minors, or by permission of instructor. Offered Fall semester only.

MUSC 297.name: Introduction to Composition
MUSC 297.descr: Group study in beginning composition. Creative writing in vocal and instrumental media.
MUSC 297.restrict: May be repeated twice for credit.

MUSC 298.name: Beginning Music Composition
MUSC 298.descr: Private study in beginning composition. Creative writing in vocal and instrumental media.
MUSC 298.restrict: Restricted to theory/composition majors. May be repeated for up to 4 credits. Offered fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 302.name: Women in Music: An Alternate Survey
MUSC 302.descr: Survey of women’s contributions to Western art music traditions from 12th century to present day through the study of women as composers, performers, patrons, and as the subject of musical expression. Explores cultural systems that have alternately encouraged and suppressed women’s creativity.
MUSC 302.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

MUSC 311.name: Music History: 400 through 1600
MUSC 311.descr: The history of musical style and theory in the Middle Ages (5th through 14th centuries) and the Renaissance (15th and 16th centuries).
MUSC 311.preReq: MUSC 196, MUSC 211, and MUSC 285 with a grade of C- or better or permission of instructor.

MUSC 312.name: Music History: 1600 through 1827
MUSC 312.descr: The history of musical style and theory during the Baroque period (1600-1750), and the Classic period through the death of Beethoven (1827).
MUSC 312.preReq: MUSC 286, MUSC 295, and MUSC 311 with a grade of C- or better or permission of instructor.

MUSC 313.name: Music History: 1827 to the Present
MUSC 313.descr: The Romantic era, Impressionism and the 20th century. Musical thought and style from 1827 to the present.
MUSC 313.preReq: MUSC 296 and MUSC 312 with a grade of C- or better or permission of instructor.

MUSC 326.name: Citizen Artistry: Engaging Communities, Classrooms, and Concert Halls
MUSC 326.descr: Students will explore definitions of “citizen artist” and “teaching artist” and how these labels connect social consciousness with their specific discipline. Students will explore Lincoln Center Education’s “Six Fundamentals of Teaching Artistry,” and experience them firsthand through sample workshops and group discussion.  Students will gain skills in regards to programming, audience engagement, curriculum integration, artistic activation, and more.
MUSC 326.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S: GROUP C: A&S Social & Behavioral Sci

MUSC 328.name: Choral Literature
MUSC 328.descr: Study of style, structure and interpretations of representative choral works, including large and small forms composed since 1500.
MUSC 328.preReq: MUSC 211 with a grade of C- or better.

MUSC 334.name: Introduction to Creative Sound Design
MUSC 334.descr: Basic course in which students engage in creating audio-visual landscapes, video with soundtrack, and songwriting through the use of digital media and sound technology.
MUSC 334.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 335.name: Basic Conducting
MUSC 335.descr: The principles of conducting and score reading.
MUSC 335.preReq: MUSC 186 and MUSC 195 with grades of C- or better.

MUSC 345.name: History of Theatre: American Musical Theatre
MUSC 345.descr: Musical-dramatic forms of the 18th, 19th and 20th centuries in the United States and their impact on the modern musical theatre. Complete works read and compared to a series of criteria that are found in successful modern shows. Comparison of older and current works.
MUSC 345.breadth: University: History and Cultural Change; A&S: GROUP B: A&S History & Cultural Change

MUSC 351.name: Private Study for Music Education V
MUSC 351.descr: Continuing private study for junior music education majors. The student adds to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, or anorchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class.
MUSC 351.preReq: MUSC 252 with a grade of C- or higher.

MUSC 352.name: Private Study for Music Education VI
MUSC 352.descr: Continuing private study for junior music education majors. The student adds to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, or an orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class.
MUSC 352.preReq: MUSC 351 with a grade of C- or higher.

MUSC 353.name: Private Study for Bachelor of Arts and Minors V
MUSC 353.descr: Continuing private study for bachelor of arts (music) students and music minors. The student adds to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, or an orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class.
MUSC 353.preReq: MUSC 254 with a grade of C- or better or permission of instructor.
MUSC 353.restrict: For bachelor of arts (music) students and music minors only. Does not count for bachelor of arts degree credit. Offered fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 354.name: Private Study for Music Bachelor of Arts and Minors VI
MUSC 354.descr: Continuing private study for bachelor of arts (music) students and music minors. The student adds to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, or an orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class.
MUSC 354.preReq: MUSC 353 with a grade of C- or better or permission of instructor.
MUSC 354.restrict: For bachelor of arts (music) students and music minors only. Does not count for bachelor of arts credit. Offered in fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 357.name: Private Study for Applied Music V
MUSC 357.descr: Continuing private study for junior applied music majors, including preparation for Junior Recital. The student adds to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, or an orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class.
MUSC 357.preReq: MUSC 252 with a grade of C- or higher.
MUSC 357.restrict: Offered in fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 358.name: Private Study for Applied Music VI
MUSC 358.descr: Continuing private study for junior applied music majors, including preparation for Junior Recital. The student adds to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, or an orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class.
MUSC 358.preReq: MUSC 357 with a grade of C- or higher.
MUSC 358.restrict: Offered in fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 363.name: Keyboard Literature
MUSC 363.descr: Style, structure and technical performance of keyboard music from the l7th century to the present.
MUSC 363.preReq: MUSC 252 or MUSC 254 with a grade of C- or better.
MUSC 363.restrict: Offered in even numbered years, fall semester only

MUSC 381.name: Private Study for Jazz and Improvisation I
MUSC 381.descr: Private study in jazz and improvisation on the student’s primary instrument for Jazz and Improvisation majors. Includes a one-hour studio class.
MUSC 381.preReq: MUSC 252 and successful completion of the sophomore review on the student’s primary instrument.

MUSC 382.name: Private Study in Jazz and Improvisation II
MUSC 382.descr: Private study in jazz and improvisation on the student’s primary instrument for Jazz and Improvisation majors. Includes a one-hour studio class.

MUSC 390.name: Jazz History and Analysis
MUSC 390.descr: Dig deeper into the theoretical, historical, cultural, and musical aspects of Jazz History.  Topics covered will include: Early Jazz styles, Bebop developments, Hard Bop and modern jazz, and theories of alternative improvisational approaches.

MUSC 391.name: Jazz Composition and Arranging
MUSC 391.descr: Composition and arranging techniques for small and large instrumental and vocal ensembles. Includes study of typical jazz notation, various voicing combinations, harmonization of melody notes, instrument characteristics, repertoire, and style.

MUSC 392.name: Contrapuntal Writing
MUSC 392.descr: Contrapuntal techniques with emphasis on 16th- and 18th-century styles and forms.
MUSC 392.preReq: MUSC 295 with a grade of C- or better.

MUSC 393.name: Keyboard Harmony
MUSC 393.descr: Practical course for the development of facility in applying knowledge of harmony to the keyboard. Emphasis on figured basis, score reading and improvisation.
MUSC 393.preReq: MUSC 276 and MUSC 295 with grades of C- or better.

MUSC 401.name: Senior Recital
MUSC 401.restrict: Requires senior status. Offered in fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 403.name: Chamber Music Literature
MUSC 403.descr: Survey of chamber music literature from the 17th century to the present.
MUSC 403.restrict: Offered in even numbered years, in spring semesters only.

MUSC 405.name: Symphonic Literature
MUSC 405.descr: Historical and structural analysis of major symphonic works from the 18th century to the present.
MUSC 405.restrict: Offered in odd numbered years, in spring semesters only.

MUSC 407.name: Contemporary Music Literature
MUSC 407.descr: Analysis of styles and techniques of contemporary composers beginning with compositions of the late 1950s.

MUSC 419.name: Introduction to Music Research
MUSC 419.descr: Designed to prepare the student to conduct extended research in music theory or musicology. The student will learn basic research methods and survey the general literature appropriate to his or her area of interest in preparation for the senior thesis.
MUSC 419.restrict: Requires permission of instructor. Limited to Music Theory and Music History and Literature Majors.

MUSC 420.name: Private Study for Advanced Composition
MUSC 420.descr: Creative writing in vocal and instrumental media.
MUSC 420.preReq: MUSC 298 with a grade of C- or better.
MUSC 420.restrict: May be repeated for up to 12 credit hours. Offered in fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 421.name: Special Projects in Music Theory
MUSC 421.descr: Theory majors do research and study under guidance of a faculty advisor on an approved topic for a formal paper to be presented at a public lecture.
MUSC 421.restrict: Offered in fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 423.name: Private Study Capstone for Advanced Composition
MUSC 423.restrict: Must be taken in the senior year.

MUSC 424.name: Marching Band Leadership Staff
MUSC 424.descr: Marching band members apply/audition for leadership roles. (Auditions each spring semester.) During fall semester, topics include challenges in peer-to-peer teaching, time management, leadership hierarchy, and developing positive leadership skills. Practical field experience is gained as students engaged in peer-to-peer teaching during marching band rehearsals and events resulting in direct application of lecture materials.
MUSC 424.preReq: 1 semester of MUSC 470 and audition in preceding spring.

MUSC 426.name: German Lieder
MUSC 426.descr: Literature survey of the standard vocal repertoire of the German tradition. Includes examples of the works of such composers as Schubert, Brahms, Schumann, Wolf and Strauss.
MUSC 426.restrict: MUSC 211 with a grade of C- or better. Offered every third spring semester, in rotation with MUSC 427 and MUSC 428.

MUSC 427.name: French Art Song
MUSC 427.descr: A literature survey of the standard vocal repertoire of the French tradition. Includes examples of the works of such composers as Faure, Debussy, Duparc and Poulenc.
MUSC 427.preReq: MUSC 211 with a grade of C- or better.
MUSC 427.restrict: Offered every third spring semester, in rotation with MUSC 426 and MUSC 428.

MUSC 428.name: Twentieth-Century Art Song
MUSC 428.descr: A literature survey of the standard vocal repertoire of the 20th Century. Includes examples of the works of such composers as Barber, Britten, Schonberg, Ives, Vaughan Williams and Rorem.
MUSC 428.preReq: MUSC 211 with a grade of C- or better.
MUSC 428.restrict: Offered every third spring semester, in rotation with MUSC 426 and MUSC 427.

MUSC 430.name: Chamber Ensemble
MUSC 430.descr: Performance of chamber literature for winds, strings, brass, percussion, piano or voice. Ensembles receive faculty coaching in addition to their regular rehearsals. Ensembles perform at least one public program per semester.
MUSC 430.restrict: May be repeated for credit. Offered fall and spring semesters.
MUSC 430.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 432.name: Studio Ensemble
MUSC 432.descr: Performance of chamber literature for ensembles that consist primarily of the same instrument type. Ensembles receive faculty coaching in addition to their regular rehearsals. Ensembles perform at least one public program per semester.
MUSC 432.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 433.name: Still Breathing
MUSC 433.descr: Still Breathing provides undergraduate students the opportunity to perform musical works by living composers, while also performing works from the 20th and 21st-century canon. The ensemble serves as an experiential vehicle for students in the areas of performance, conducting and organization. In addition, students enrolled in this ensemble can also participate in the ‘free improvisation’ group, SCI Improv. This ensemble is open to all students in the UD School of Music.
MUSC 433.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 438.name: Practical Studies in World Percussion
MUSC 438.descr: The objective of this course is to introduce students to instruments and music from around the world that have a heavy emphasis on percussion. Students will receive hands-on experience allowing them to create and develop a basic technical facility on each instrument and musical style studied in the course. They will then apply these techniques to help understand traditional music of various cultures including West Africa, Brazil, Middle Eastern, Latin America, and the Caribbean.
MUSC 438.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 441.name: Accompanying Chamber Music: Piano
MUSC 441.descr: Accompanying vocalists and instrumentalists and experiences with piano, chamber and large ensembles, and degree recitals.
MUSC 441.restrict: Requires permission of instructor. Offered fall and spring semesters. May be repeated 1 time for credit.

MUSC 451.name: Private Study for Music Education VII
MUSC 451.descr: Continuing private study for senior music education majors. The student adds to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, or an orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class.
MUSC 451.preReq: MUSC 352 with a grade of C- or higher.

MUSC 452.name: Private Study for Music Education VIII
MUSC 452.descr: Optional continuing private study for senior music education majors. The student adds to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, or an orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class.
MUSC 452.preReq: MUSC 451 with a grade of C- or better.
MUSC 452.restrict: For music education majors only. Offered fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 453.name: Private Study for Bachelor of Arts and Minors VII
MUSC 453.descr: Continuing private study for bachelor of arts (music) students and music minors. The student adds to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, or an orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class.
MUSC 453.preReq: MUSC 354, with a grade of C- or better, or permission of instructor.
MUSC 453.restrict: For bachelor of arts (music) students and music minors only. Does not count for bachelor of arts degree credit. Offered fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 454.name: Private Study for Music Bachelor of Arts and Minors VIII
MUSC 454.descr: Continuing private study for bachelor of arts (music) students and music minors. The student adds to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, or an orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class.
MUSC 454.preReq: MUSC 353 with a grade of C- or better, or permission of instructor.
MUSC 454.restrict: For bachelor of arts (music) students and music minors only. Does not count for bachelor of arts degree credit. Offered fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 457.name: Private Study for Applied Music VII
MUSC 457.descr: Continuing private study for senior applied music majors, including preparation for Senior Recital. The student adds to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, or an orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class.
MUSC 457.preReq: MUSC 358 with a grade of C- or higher.
MUSC 457.restrict: Offered in fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 458.name: Private Study for Applied Music VIII
MUSC 458.descr: Continuing private study for senior applied music majors, including preparation for Senior Recital. The student adds to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, or an orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class.
MUSC 458.preReq: MUSC 457 with a grade of C- or higher.
MUSC 458.restrict: Offered in fall and spring semesters.

MUSC 460.name: University Singers
MUSC 460.descr: Members enter by audition. A chorus of sopranos and altos that performs its own concerts and may also perform with other choirs.
MUSC 460.restrict: May be repeated for credit. Offered in fall and spring semesters.
MUSC 460.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 461.name: Schola Cantorum
MUSC 461.descr: Members enter by audition. A chorus of 100+ voices that rehearses en masse on Monday nights and performs large-scale choral works. Smaller sections perform independently as well.
MUSC 461.restrict: May be repeated for credit. Offered in fall and spring semesters.
MUSC 461.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 462.name: Concert Choir
MUSC 462.descr: Select ensemble open to all students by permission of professor, as determined by audition. Rehearses and performs exemplary choral repertoire ranging from Renaissance to works by contemporary composers. Additional emphasis given to fostering healthy vocal production and development of sight singing skills.
MUSC 462.restrict: May be repeated for credit. Offered in fall and spring semesters.
MUSC 462.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 463.name: Chorale
MUSC 463.descr: Members enter by audition. Chorale is the university’s most select chorus of mixed voices.
MUSC 463.restrict: May be repeated for credit. Offered in fall and spring semesters.
MUSC 463.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 464.name: Internship
MUSC 464.descr: Field experience with nonprofit performing arts organizations or commercial music businesses relevant to the student’s area of interest.

MUSC 470.name: Marching Band
MUSC 470.descr: All interested percussionists, colorguard and twirlers must audition. May be repeated for credit. Offered in fall semester only.
MUSC 470.restrict: Contact the Director for detailed information. All interested percussionists, colorguard and twirlers must audition. May be repeated for credit. Offered in fall semester only.
MUSC 470.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 471.name: Symphonic Band
MUSC 471.descr: Sixty-five to 70 member ensemble performs standard concert literature as well as new compositions.
MUSC 471.restrict: Requires audition. May be repeated for credit. Offered in fall and spring semesters.
MUSC 471.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 472.name: Wind Ensemble
MUSC 472.descr: Select 45-member group of woodwind, brass and percussion players that performs original band music, chamber music and transcriptions.
MUSC 472.restrict: Requires audition and may be repeated for credit. Offered in fall and spring semesters.
MUSC 472.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 473.name: Symphony Orchestra
MUSC 473.descr: Plays at least four public programs per year, drawn from music masterworks in all styles and periods from Baroque to Contemporary.Featured are faculty, professional soloists, conductors and collaborations with other University ensembles.
MUSC 473.restrict: Requires audition. May be repeated for credit. Offered in fall and spring semesters.
MUSC 473.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 474.name: Chamber Orchestra
MUSC 474.descr: A small, highly select group of orchestral musicians. The group performs one program of challenging, sophisticated music each semester both on and off campus.
MUSC 474.restrict: Requires audition.  May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 474.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 475.name: Opera Orchestra
MUSC 475.descr: A small, highly select group of orchestral musicians. This ensemble participates in UD Opera Theatre productions.
MUSC 475.restrict: Requires audition. May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 475.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S:

MUSC 476.name: Collegium Musicum
MUSC 476.descr: Ensemble for the performance of instrumental and vocal music from the Medieval, Renaissance and Early Baroque periods. Size, instrumentation, and repertoire of the group varies between semesters depending on resources at hand, players’ skills, and other factors.
MUSC 476.restrict: May be repeated for credit. Offered in fall and spring semesters.
MUSC 476.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 477.name: Jazz Ensemble
MUSC 477.descr: Study and performance of the diverse styles characteristic of the medium.
MUSC 477.restrict: Requires audition. May be repeated for credit. Offered in fall and spring semesters.
MUSC 477.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 478.name: Percussion Ensemble
MUSC 478.descr: Study and performance of works for percussion instruments.
MUSC 478.restrict: Requires audition. May be repeated for credit. Offered in fall and spring semesters.
MUSC 478.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 480.name: Vocal Pedagogy
MUSC 480.descr: Designed for those who plan to work with the singing voice. Includes vocal research, comparative pedagogy, observation of teaching and practical teaching experience.

MUSC 481.name: Pedagogy and Literature
MUSC 481.descr: The study of teaching methods and literature (music scores, books, and other media). Shows teaching skills needed at the secondary level and lower.

MUSC 482.name: Private Study in Jazz and Improvisation III
MUSC 482.descr: Private study in jazz and improvisation on the student’s primary instrument for Jazz and Improvisation majors. Includes a one-hour studio class.

MUSC 483.name: Private Study in Jazz and Improvisation IV
MUSC 483.descr: Private study in jazz and improvisation on the student’s primary instrument for Jazz and Improvisation majors. Includes a one-hour studio class.

MUSC 484.name: Recording Techniques
MUSC 484.descr: Covers three parameters: history of recording and recording technology; recording techniques with hands-on experiences; and aesthetics of recording and its impact on music through the 20th and 21st centuries.

MUSC 485.name: Principles of Music Industry Practice
MUSC 485.descr: Offers an understanding of the fundamental workings of the music industry. Examines theory/practice of core principles, focusing on provisions of copyright law, standard agreements, and professional organization influences. Emphasis on framework for interaction among writers, artists, performers, publishers, record companies, producers.

MUSC 486.name: Elements of Music Management
MUSC 486.descr: Introduces principles involved in planning and management for performing arts organizations. Includes basic concepts of project development and implementation, production issues for public performances, communication skills and marketing techniques, utilization of new technologies, and aspects of resource planning and advocacy.
MUSC 486.restrict: Open to juniors and seniors. Offered fall semester only.

MUSC 487.name: Patterns of Patronage
MUSC 487.descr: Examines the creation, performance and transmission of music within broader context of the economic, political, social and technological environment. Emphasizes interdependency of musical activity and its patrons, including traditional functions of state, church, civic, mercantile, private; also contemporary interaction with public, private, and third sectors.
MUSC 487.restrict: Open to juniors and seniors. Offered spring semester only.
MUSC 487.breadth: University: Social and Behavioral Sciences; A&S:

MUSC 489.name: Opera Workshop
MUSC 489.descr: Dramatic and musical preparation of operatic roles through the production of opera scenes or chamber opera.
MUSC 489.restrict: Admission by audition, with permission of private instructor. Offered fall and spring semesters. Students may sign up for 0-credit only if they have reached the 17-credit limit. Music majors and minors must be enrolled for credit in at least one departmentally approved ensemble during each semester of private study.

MUSC 490.name: Opera Theatre
MUSC 490.descr: Participation and performance in University of Delaware Opera Theatre’s fall or spring Mainstage productions. Rehearsals will include musical preparation, musical coaching, and staging. Additional outside rehearsals and coachings may be required and will vary based on repertoire choices.
MUSC 490.preReq: Admission by audition, with permission of private instructor.
MUSC 490.restrict: Auditions for Mainstage productions and casting decisions for the following year are made at the very end of the Spring semester, so those interested in participating are encouraged to contact UD Opera Theatre staff as early as possible.

MUSC 491.name: Global Improvisation
MUSC 491.descr: A performance/workshop class designed to encourage musical creativity, providing students with techniques and strategies for musical improvisation within a collaborative, supportive, and structured environment. The class will include instruction in many aspects of improvisation, using regular audio and video examples of improvisational music to expose students to the varied ways which creative musicians use improvisation. The majority of student’s time, however, will be spent playing for each other to build confidence and gain knowledge through personal experience.
MUSC 491.breadth: University: Creative Arts and Humanities; A&S: GROUP A: A&S Creative Arts & Humanities

MUSC 495.name: Analysis and Interpretation
MUSC 495.descr: Structure of homophonic and polyphonic music representing different periods of musical history.
MUSC 495.preReq: MUSC 295 with a grade of C- or better.

MUSC 499.name: Music Portfolio Capstone Project
MUSC 499.restrict: Students can only take the course in their senior year, with permission of the instructor.

MUSC 511.name: Historical Foundations Review
MUSC 511.restrict: Does not count toward credits for degree.

MUSC 561.name: Non-Degree Private Study
MUSC 561.descr: Continuing private study for all music majors. The student adds to the course title the branch of study elected: piano, organ, voice, or an orchestral instrument. Includes a one-hour studio class.

MUSC 600.name: Master’s Performance in Conducting
MUSC 600.restrict: For students in the Master of Music degree, Performance Concentration (Conducting).

MUSC 602.name: Advanced Keyboard Literature
MUSC 602.descr: An historical survey of selected keyboard works from various style periods, including structural analysis and performance implications.

MUSC 603.name: Chamber Music Literature
MUSC 603.descr: Survey of chamber music literature from the 17th century to the present.
MUSC 603.restrict: Requires permission of instructor. Offered in even numbered years, in spring semester only.

MUSC 605.name: Symphonic Literature
MUSC 605.descr: Historical and structural analysis of major symphonic works from the 18th century to the present.
MUSC 605.restrict: Requires permission of instructor. Offered in odd numbered years, in spring semester only.

MUSC 606.name: Wind Literature
MUSC 606.descr: History of the wind band and its music from the Renaissance to the present, with emphasis on the wind music from the 19th and 20th centuries for wind ensemble and concert band. Examines wind literature suitable for secondary school and college-level performing groups.

MUSC 607.name: Contemporary Music Literature
MUSC 607.descr: Analysis of styles and techniques of contemporary composers beginning with compositions of the late 1950s.
MUSC 607.restrict: Requires permission of instructor. Offered in fall semeter only.

MUSC 608.name: Vocal Literature I: Song
MUSC 608.descr: A survey of important literature for solo voice. Focus on German Lieder, French Art Song, and twentieth-century Art Song.

MUSC 609.name: Choral Music Literature I
